headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by and welcome to News Corp.'s Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And at this time, I will turn the conference call over to your host, Senior Vice President, Investor
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by and welcome to News Corp.'s Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And at this time, I will turn the conference call over to your host, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations for News Corp., Reed Nolte. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello everyone and welcome to our second quarter fiscal 2010 earnings conference call. On the call today are: Rupert Murdoch, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dave
componenttext: Thank you very much, operator. Hello everyone and welcome to our second quarter fiscal 2010 earnings conference call. On the call today are: Rupert Murdoch, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dave DeVoe, our CFO. Dave will give a detailed presentation of the quarter results, followed by Rupert, who will give his own perspective and color on the quarter. We'll then take your questions, first from the financial community and then from the press. This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to News Corporation's businesses and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. News Corporation's Form 10-Q for the three months ended December 31, 2009, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ, and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such a filing.Additionally in this quarter, you may have noticed that we have changed the presentation format of the consolidated income statement to no longer display an operating income caption. Instead, we provide the measurement of total segment operating income in the earnings release and notes to our financial statements. As contrasted to our prior reporting of operating income, the only difference is that total segment operating income excludes impairment and restructuring charges. Prior periods have been revised to conform to this new presentation.Total segment operating income is a non-GAAP financial measure. The definition of and a reconciliation of total segment operating income to income before taxes is provided in both the earnings release and our 10-Q filing. In addition, we may refer to the other non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures can be found on our website. If you have any questions on the presentation, you can contact me after the call. And with that, I'll turn it over to Dave.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Reed, thank you very much and good afternoon, everybody. At the outset of the call, I'd like to note that our reported results this quarter reflect a one-time charge related to the previously announced settlement of litigation involving the company's Inte
componenttext: Reed, thank you very much and good afternoon, everybody. At the outset of the call, I'd like to note that our reported results this quarter reflect a one-time charge related to the previously announced settlement of litigation involving the company's Integrated Marketing Service segment. The related $500 million pretax settlement charge is reflected in this quarter's segment operating income and it had a $315 million or $0.12 per share net income effect.After adjusting for this item, we are extremely pleased with the underlying strong financial results we reported for the second quarter of fiscal 2010 where total segment operating income reached $1.2 billion. This is an improvement of 44% from a year ago and this improvement rises to 50% factoring in the absence of the results from NDS, which are no longer consolidated this year. This increase was fueled by a 10% overall revenue growth and was further supported by the cost reduction efforts we initiated over the past several years. Our reported net income in the quarter was $254 million with earnings per share of $0.10. This compares to a reported loss of $6.4 billion or $2.45 per share last year. However, excluding the net income effects in both years at one-time items, such as the litigation charge this year and the impairment charge we took last year, second quarter earnings per share this year were $0.25 as compared to the year ago results of $0.15.Now, I'd like to provide some context on some of the results at our segments. Now let's start with the Film segment where second quarter operating income was $324 million. This is up $212 million over last year's result, with revenue growth of 28%. This strong performance was led by the worldwide home entertainment release of Ice Age, Dawn of the Dinosaurs and also reflected a other home entertainment releases including Wolverine and a Night at the Museum.December quarter also included significant launch costs for our very successful theatrical releases of Avatar and Alvin and the Chipmunks. The profits from these films will begin to flow in the next quarter, which is our third quarter of the year. At our Television segment, operating income in the quarter of $29 million improved by $31 million as compared to the second quarter a year ago, and this is driven by a 19% higher television station contribution and improved results at MyNetworkTV. And after six consecutive quarters of year-over-year declines, Station revenues were up 6% in the current quarter, and this reflects improved local advertising trends, particularly in the telecommunications, retail, fast food, and finance sectors, as well as improved sports advertising from considerably higher ratings in the Major League Baseball postseason on Fox.The growth was achieved despite a significant reduction of Political Advertising revenues versus last year. And I think it's worth noting that we saw significant improvements at the Station as the quarter progressed. And for example, we began with October being down 14% versus a year ago and ended up in December being up 28%, and these positive trends, which Rupert probably talked more about have continued into the current quarter.Now moving on to the Cable Network segment where we continue to show very strong growth. With record -- now record segment operating income contributions of $604 million, and this is up 35% from last year on revenue growth of 18%. The revenue growth was led by a 21% increase in affiliate revenue and high single-digit growth in advertising. The largest year-over-year gains in the quarter were from the FOX News Channel. This is due to higher affiliate rates and additional subscribers and a relatively flat cost base. The international channels from affiliate revenue increases. Ad gains and the advertisements was particularly strong in Europe and in Latin America. The regional sports networks, which reflect higher advertising rates and essentially flat advertising revenues, and at STAR, which has been included in this segment since last quarter. We have significant growth in advertising revenues in India, this is led by the ratings strength of our regional channel.Turning to our Pay Television business, SKY Italia generated a segment operating loss of $30 million as compared to income of $10 million in the second quarter a year ago. SKY Italia continues to operate in an extremely challenging business and economic environment and subscriber growth is clearly below our expectation. However, it is important to note that this is a very profitable business but we remain confident in the longer-term growth in this under penetrated market. In the quarter, SKY Italia total revenues decline by 2% in local currency term, as compared to the prior year's quarter. Monthly ARPU in the quarter averaged around EUR 43 as compared to last year's EUR 45, and this reflects the lower average tier mix, reduced pay-per-view revenue and the lag effects of various price promotions.Overall, costs in the quarter were flat as higher our soccer costs were offset by savings in other programming. SKY Italia's subscriber base declined by 63,000 compared with the previous quarter, and has total quarterly gross additions of 150,000 and more than offset by churn. This puts our anti-subscriber levels at approximately 4.75 million.At quarter end, over 2.1 million subscribers, representing approximately 47% of the subscriber base were taking at least one premium service compared with approximately 22% of the subscriber base a year ago. The importance of this is that, the premium-service subscribers churn rate are about one fifth of the non-premium service subscribers.Shifting to our Newspaper Information Service segment, our operating income in this year's quarter was $259 million, and this is up 30% from what we reported a year ago. This improvement is largely driven by higher advertising of the Wall Street Journal and lower operating expenses throughout all of our newspaper businesses. Our newspaper results also benefited from a favorable foreign exchange impact on revenues and segment operating income, primarily from the relative strengthening of the Australian dollar versus the U.S. dollar. And like at our TV stations, compared to advertising revenues at our Newspapers improved as the quarter progressed.At our Book Publishing segment, operating income contributions of $65 million in the quarter increased by $42 million, primarily due to higher revenues in our general book in Children's Books divisions as well as reduced operating expenses resulting from last year's restructuring efforts.In our Other segment, we reported a second quarter operating loss of $125 million compared to a loss of $38 million a year ago. Approximately 40% of this change reflects the absence of NDS operating profit this year due to the partial sale of NDS in early February 2009 and NDS is now accounted for its equity company. Additionally, the Digital Media Group's earnings declined from last year due to lower advertising and search revenues at MySpace. This is offset in part by cost reductions and restructuring efforts. Before I address our guidance, I just want to make a couple of comments related to our balance sheet. We reported a cash balance at quarter end of nearly $7.3 billion. A portion of is this balance will be used to reduce debt in the current quarter as we have $150 million senior note maturity, which comes due in March. And today, we committed to satisfying cash to put, if exercised by holders on the $1.7 million of debt that is convertible into shares that we own at BSkyB. Investors have until March 10 to notify the company of their decision. And also today, we announced a 25% increase in the company's dividend of $0.06 per share to $0.075 per share.And finally, before turning the call over to Rupert, let me address our guidance for fiscal 2010. And as a reminder, as we did at year end to that, our first quarter this year, we measured this guidance excluding from fiscal 2009 segment operating income results $121 million in operating profit from NDS, which is no longer consolidated in our results. So as we look at measuring growth in fiscal 2010, we are comparing it to a base of $3.44 billion in segment operating profit for fiscal 2009.In early November, we gave guidance and anticipated our segment operating income growth rate for fiscal 2010 to be in a high single-digit to low double-digit range, above the $3.44 billion in fiscal 2009 adjusted results. Since that time, we performed better than anticipated and several of our businesses. The box office records being set by Avatar has raised our outlook for the Filmed Entertainment segment. The U.S. Television environment is reporting better than we had assumed as our Newspapers.And the impact of recent negotiations with cable operators can now be considered. Partially offsetting these improvements, operating conditions in Italy continue to be more difficult than earlier anticipated, and it is taking longer than we expected to achieve our revenue goals at some of our digital media business groups including MySpace. As a result, in taking all these items into account, and excluding the effect of the litigation settlement and the restructuring-related charges, we are increasing our segment operating income growth, guidance to a growth rate in the low 20% range above the fiscal 2009 adjusted results. And with that, I like to now turn the call over to Rupert for some additional comments.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. Good afternoon, everyone. As David just described, our true operating results for this past quarter were extraordinary. We've endured the most severe recession since the Great Depression but have emerged on this turbulence and turmoil, I
componenttext: Thank you, Dave. Good afternoon, everyone. As David just described, our true operating results for this past quarter were extraordinary. We've endured the most severe recession since the Great Depression but have emerged on this turbulence and turmoil, I think, as the world's preeminent content company. A crisis recasts companies and economies. The crisis highlights weaknesses and expedites pre-existing trends.From a crisis comes clarity and the strength of our company and our strategy is clear for all to see. Excuse the immodesty, but News Corporation's pre-eminence as a content creator comes as the debate over the privacy of content is over. Content is not just king, it is the emperor of all things electronic. We are on the cusp of the digital dynasty from which our company and our shareholders will profit greatly.Devices and platforms are proliferating but this clever technology is merely an empty vessel without any great content. Machines are not powered by batteries but by creativity and ingenuity, by content that is original, accessible and trusted. Those characteristics define the nature of our company and are the pillars on which we are building a profitable future. It's worth taking a moment to put the company's content into context.We have the world leading drum studio, which has just made the most successful film in cinematic history. We are thrilled that the confidence we placed in Avatar and its talented team led by James Cameron had been recognized by appreciative audiences around the world and is still being recognized. And just this morning, it was nominated for nine Academy Awards including Best Picture. Beyond this stunning financial success, I'm convinced Avatar will be a harbinger of fundamental change in the industry and herald an exciting new era of 3D entertainment. It's worth recalling, as Dave explained, in the most recent quarter, we booked much of the film's costs and only a small portion of the receipts.In the current quarter and beyond, Avatar will provide a strong stream of revenue for our company. The studio's other hits included Ice Age 3 and Alvin and the Chipmunks, both of which helped us surpass $4 billion in worldwide box office this past year, an industry record.Also we have the number one broadcast network in the United States, FBC, which has been the top-rated network for the past six seasons on the strength of shows like American Idol, which just kicked off its ninth season and is as dominant as ever. And this past fall was the strongest in the network's history. Our television production studio along the place for such brand name shows like The Simpsons and 24 is now home to more new hit series than any other studio with shows like Modern Family, Glee and the Cleveland Show.We have America's number one newspaper in the Wall Street Journal, number one in terms of circulation, influence and quality. While other prominent papers are still suffering year-on-year advertising and circulation declines, the opposite is true at the Journal. The wsj.com remains the digital model for newspapers around the world with a strong subscription base and still growing advertising revenue.In the United Kingdom, we have the number one newspaper in the Sun, which had record weeks of advertising revenues during this past quarter and has left the other papers far, far behind in the contest for readers. In Australia, we have the largest selling daily paper, the Herald Sun, which grew circulation while the Australian, our national daily, achieved strong advertising marketing share growth as well as increasing its position as the most influential paper in the country.The FOX News Channel is certainly the number one news channel in the U.S., winning an ever greater share of an audience that is both loyal and lucrative. Roger Ailes has done a remarkable and admirable job in building the world's most influential and profitable news network. Through Fox International Channels, we have launched more cable channels around the globe than any other company and we are profiting from continuing growth in Asia and rapidly expanding middle-class audiences elsewhere in the world. While the West was coping with the crisis, the economic emancipation of much of the developing world continue their enormous unprecedented pace as our unique success with STAR in India testifies.  And HarperCollins is one of the world's leading publishing houses with much improved profitability. There's no doubt that we've been at the forefront of the global debate about that value of content. At times, that debate has been intense but that was essential when the stakes were so high. Far too many content companies were passive in the face of predatory behavior and self-serving sophistry. Passivity and meekness are not characteristics of our company. A year ago, our criticism was thought heretical. But somehow, the profane has become profound and the content plan has gathered around our ideas. As I said earlier, the value of content is now clear. Instead of the existential debate about value, now we are merely haggling over valuations.Consumers want content to be delivered immediately and on array of devices that suit their needs and they are willing to be pay, to be entertained and informed. Our mission is clear and coherent. It is to create great content and customize it to suit our expanding audiences around the world. In the last couple of months, I have toured the most innovative Asian research laboratories and walked the floor at the Consumer Electronic Show. The message is the same everywhere. Without content, the ever larger and flatter screens, the tablets, the e-readers and the increasingly sophisticated mobile phones would be lifeless. Without content, these ingenious and wonderful devices would be unloved and unsold.And I'm delighted though certainly not complacent that our employees' creativity and energy have been paid the ultimate compliment by consumers. They have paid for our content.As Dave pointed out, our results, almost across the board, far outpaced those of the same quarter last year. Our revenues have revived and should remain strong. Local and national television advertising markets have been surprisingly strong. The signs  are that this trend will continue in coming months. But the truth is that the advertising cycle has shortened and we all have limited ability to peer into the future. The broadcast network business was thought moribund by many, but we fundamentally changed its fortunes with a groundbreaking retransmission consent deal we made a few weeks ago. The precedent we have established means that the retransmission fees we will be renegotiating with cable and satellite providers as our current deals expire over the next couple of years will breathe new life into that business.When it comes to online news, we have committed to changing that model, too. We are in advanced discussions with other media companies around the world, all of them have turned to our company for ideas and innovation. We are currently in the midst of a very substantive conversations with device makers on developing subscription model that will develop high-quality journalism to consumers wherever and whenever they want it. We've begun to charge for online content of a couple of our U.S. titles and we expect to expand to other titles in the coming months. We have the most experience given our success in various digital offerings of the Wall Street Journal.The success in 3D of Avatar and Ice Age 3 and our experience in being the most innovative broadcaster of sports events puts us in a prime position for the development of the next generation of 3D consumer technology. Asian manufacturers are well advanced in developing the technology that will transform the home viewing experience. Of course you will see more 3D films, but more fundamentally, there'll be exponential growth in 3D programming in the next couple of years. Follow-on this experience in leading the development of high-definition viewing in Britain, BSkyB will be launching a 3D channel in the very near future. Only last night, they made their first 3D broadcast.As well-positioned as we are, there remain a few areas of our business that are not performing as well as we would like that continue to be long term growth drivers. The first is SKY Italia. As David noted, SKY Italia is faced with tough economic environment and increased competition but we are certainly enthusiastic about the potential of this business given the high quality of our service and the low penetration of paid television in Italy. The second is our affiliate Sky Deutschland. We have great confidence that the new management team headed by Brian Sullivan who helped build BSkyB into a power house. We'd be able to make headway in another big market with very low pay TV penetration.As proof of our confidence in this business, we just increased our stake by five percentage points. Despite the challenges in these markets, we remain firm in our commitment to pay TV around the world. And then there is MySpace but is not yet there we want it. MySpace remains one of the world's top Web destinations. And during the past quarter, we started to see signs of traffic stabilization as its mission was clarified. We believe the stability points to progress the new management team has made in repositioning MySpace as the prime place where people share thoughts and ideas about music, entertainment and other popular content.Finally, after all I've just said about the recent achievements of our company, I think the most important point I can make overall is that these businesses are growing. Not just surviving, but thriving. The majority of our business segments reported double-digit revenue growth this past quarter, clearly driving our higher operating profits. It's a widespread improvement that we believe will continue in the coming quarters. And I have to say that kind of success comes with having great depth of leadership. At News Corporation, we have the best leaders in the media business. Chase Carey is a wonderful partner and his strategic focus, dynamic ideas and willingness to take on tough issues have helped to reinvigorate all of us. And with some of the recent executives moves we've made at Dow Jones, our FOX businesses, our international newspapers and the restructuring of our STAR Asia business, we think repositioned for an exciting new chapter for News Corporation.  Thank you very much. And now, Chase, Dave and I will be happy to take any of your questions.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, chase, question regarding the retransmission consent. How big a deal is this retransmission consent? One, are there a lot more coming up in the near future? and over the next three to five years, should we be thinking $40 million a month
componenttext: I was wondering, chase, question regarding the retransmission consent. How big a deal is this retransmission consent? One, are there a lot more coming up in the near future? and over the next three to five years, should we be thinking $40 million a month or $100 million a month coming out of retransmission consent?

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm probably not going to quantify it with specificity at this point. What is clear is the transforming event. It really puts the network on a path where it's a profitable business that generates the type of profit that I think it should for the audience
componenttext: I'm probably not going to quantify it with specificity at this point. What is clear is the transforming event. It really puts the network on a path where it's a profitable business that generates the type of profit that I think it should for the audience and the importance it represents in the marketplace. In terms of timing, we've got two of the top 10 distributors done. So we, obviously, are in early stages. There really are two fronts to this issue. One is through our ONOs where we deal directly with distributors. And then the second is through the affiliate body. First, on the arena where we deal directly, it's about a three to four-year process and the next two years about half of the distribution universe is up with us and we'll deal with it. In terms of the affiliates, we're engaged now. Look, we've been with affiliates, we think we value the relationship, we think it is important that we reach a fair conclusion. Now that being said, we think the network is the most valuable and important programming that we provide to consumers. And we've begun those discussions but those discussions will really probably continue in the months to come. But certainly, they will move forward. We are engaged now and will move forward on those. And again, probably with the affiliates, their deals come up with distributors likewise and probably that same three-plus year time frame. So I think that's the broad concept. I do think -- obviously, we have a lot of work left to do but I don't believe this really kind of does set us on course and points at a direction that the Fox network can assume the role it should. It's the most important television channel we have. It is the force that drives our Television business and it should generate profits to reflect that and we think we've set it on that course.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: So this fixes the Broadcast business model?
componenttext: So this fixes the Broadcast business model?

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I think you put us on a -- probably sense, overly simply to say,  everything's fixed. I mean, we have great management there. We got the run it. We on are the number one network. I think it puts us on a course where we can generate the profits
componenttext: Yes. Look, I think you put us on a -- probably sense, overly simply to say,  everything's fixed. I mean, we have great management there. We got the run it. We on are the number one network. I think it puts us on a course where we can generate the profits we should. If we generate that, we are going to feed for a good network. And so yes, I think it's -- I guess, simplistically you could say it fixes it but it certainly puts it in a competitive place where it has a dual revenue stream like successful cable networks does and those that it increasingly competes to.

componenttextpreview: On the ad market, it really does continue, that could be -- on a positive, it continues to be up really a good back and a very solid strong ad market. The network is still doing sort of scatter business at the 15% sort of the mid-teens above the upfront.
componenttext: On the ad market, it really does continue, that could be -- on a positive, it continues to be up really a good back and a very solid strong ad market. The network is still doing sort of scatter business at the 15% sort of the mid-teens above the upfront. The cable channels in a really solid double digits in news. The entertainment business on the cable side, probably in the neighborhood of 20% above upfront. The sports, which has probably been the one that is probably had the toughest road to hold given kind of seeing some kind of a reverse like autos, so it's actually stronger than it's been. So the ad market has really been a solid market in the station business. I think Dave said it, I mean, the Station business again, we got a quarter that looks like it will be sort of mid-to high teens you an up year on year. You still have an environment and I know it say that you don't have the visibility historically you had and people talk about the economy and how reliable are some of the positive things you're seeing. But certainly those qualifications certainly, what we're experiencing in dealing within the market place so all continues to be a positive from an advertising perspective, really across stations network cable.

And are we down on the boom years of two years ago? Yes, certainly. But our profits are very well up on last year.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question on SKY Italia. It looks like this year, you could see margins may be back to the '07 levels. And I assume you think you can increase subs by at least a couple of million overtime. So I am wondering what should we look at as maybe a leadi
componenttext: I have a question on SKY Italia. It looks like this year, you could see margins may be back to the '07 levels. And I assume you think you can increase subs by at least a couple of million overtime. So I am wondering what should we look at as maybe a leading indicator for improvement in the business? Is it less promotion, the economy, political, something else? And are we at a point now where the soccer and programming costs are largely fixed so we can see a start of a margin ramp going forward when  you see the sub-gains?

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I think as we look at SKY Italia, I mean, I think if I look next calendar year roughly, probably it's not up here where we're focused on sub-growth. So I think it probably is a more stable sub-environment, getting used to that tough economy. So we're comi
componenttext: I think as we look at SKY Italia, I mean, I think if I look next calendar year roughly, probably it's not up here where we're focused on sub-growth. So I think it probably is a more stable sub-environment, getting used to that tough economy. So we're coming through these things, we sort of really getting to the end of digesting the price increase, the bad increase that occurred close to a year ago, so it helps us as we absorb that. And I think we had to adjust to some of the issues in terms of selling our product, the loss of advertising space on the media sat channels. And again I think we're making adjustments and the court has given us right to do it. But I think we're again sort of appropriately getting on top of that. I think given that environment, our focus in the short term will again be stabilizing that appropriately, managing the business in a tough environment. I think if you look through toward the end of the year going forward, we do really still think we have a lot of some growth in front of us. So it's a market still at 30% pay penetration. I think we have a great product. I think we have a great brand, great franchise in the marketplace. And we really should be able to build on that position as we go forward. A soccer deal is we have a deal done for three years so we have CPI-type increases in the next three years, so we have pretty predictable situation in terms of those costs. And I think our focus in the short term, again, we will probably be on stabilizing the business, dealing with some of the issues we've had like churn. When churn has been a challenge in this year, again, somehow with the price increase, the market itself, but I think we feel we're taking these steps to get on top of it so I guess does that will go look for something in the short term. I think something like churn would be the type of measure we'd be focused on improving efficiencies and really stabilizing that business in a tough environment setting it up the ground, which is should.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: For Rupert and Chaise, I wanted to ask about growth prospects for cable networks profits have increased over a fourfold from 2004 to now, at least to what it looks like a $1.2 billion plus of EBIT this year. The last year, two had a good chunk that was dr
componenttext: For Rupert and Chaise, I wanted to ask about growth prospects for cable networks profits have increased over a fourfold from 2004 to now, at least to what it looks like a $1.2 billion plus of EBIT this year. The last year, two had a good chunk that was driven by Fox new renewals. So I was hoping you could help us understand how much growth is left at cable networks? Can you breakdown the drivers of growth from. And also indicate how much longer can cable nets maintain double-digit profit growth, that'd be helpful.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly in Sky News we've had most of the effect of the big increase in the price we're charging for, but we have another you to go before everybody kicks in. It probably will be as big an increase as this year but is a very solid one, turning it
componenttext: Well, certainly in Sky News we've had most of the effect of the big increase in the price we're charging for, but we have another you to go before everybody kicks in. It probably will be as big an increase as this year but is a very solid one, turning it big double-figure. And if you look at the overall, we think we have great potential for growth in our existing channels, both as profits and in distribution. We've got quite a long way to go yet. When you look at the profits of a long-established channels like USA, we've got plenty of room for growth.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd second that. I mean, I think you can look at it sort of in two levels, I think it means the U.S., I think you're going to head to a period where it's quality over quantity. I think you said that before. I think if you've got really strong channel
componenttext: Yes, I'd second that. I mean, I think you can look at it sort of in two levels, I think it means the U.S., I think you're going to head to a period where it's quality over quantity. I think you said that before. I think if you've got really strong channels you should be able to buy them. I think we're more popular than ever. I think we're going to continue to take share and you'll look at our big driving channels and as Rupert said, I mean, FX is nowhere near what USA generates and Nat Geo, nowhere near what something like Discovery generates. Fox news just continues to get stronger and stronger. I don't know that there is a channel that is more important or powerful in television universe in the U.S. So I think that channel has great upside to it. So I think those powerful channels, which are going to drive it have a lot of room left to grow. And we are simply bullish about in the other -- the international marketplace, which is the other front, really had its core, is going up and it's going to get driven up as the international pay TV business really follows the U.S. business in terms of growth and penetration first and foremost. We now -- we are leader in most of the places we deal we do business. So we're in a great position to take advantage of those markets as they grow in terms of size and penetration and the like. So we think that business has, internationally, has enormous growth. Ahead of it as the market grows and we take advantage of the position that we have in those competitive markets. So I guess the business that has lot of room to grow. And everybody ask there where's money come from? Realistically, we want good relationships with distributors but you have to see if theirs are making a lot of money, with big healthy profit margins. So I guess those will be the negotiations that we have in the market place. And how you get the fair share, get our fair share for the quality of the content we have.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: But do you know -- does it basically throughout the world outside of America, which is pretty fully develop, you've got about a 20% growth in pay television wherever you look, wherever it's available in the world. And we were on those platforms, we get th
componenttext: But do you know -- does it basically throughout the world outside of America, which is pretty fully develop, you've got about a 20% growth in pay television wherever you look, wherever it's available in the world. And we were on those platforms, we get that 20% growth. We expect to put other channels on, to build the challenge more, to improve them. We got a very big future ahead of us there. I think we've really only just started.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We haven't put a data out. I mean, we're not getting -- it won't be 3d. We'll have actually a second copy. I mean, one of the opportunities we have is that, of all these the 3D avatar down the road, but I don't spot this window. But the one thing I w
componenttext: Yes. We haven't put a data out. I mean, we're not getting -- it won't be 3d. We'll have actually a second copy. I mean, one of the opportunities we have is that, of all these the 3D avatar down the road, but I don't spot this window. But the one thing I will say in the film if you look at year-to-year, we had some pretty good second half last year. And so as to what's driving our year-over-year compared when you get to the second half, I mean we have a really pretty good film here in the second half. So I wouldn't say it's film that's driving the second half.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on the sole retrans issue. Chase, I think you said at an analyst conference or investor conference several months ago, that ESPN gets $5 a month, basically why shouldn't Fox be getting $5 a month. And I guess, you had incredible
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the sole retrans issue. Chase, I think you said at an analyst conference or investor conference several months ago, that ESPN gets $5 a month, basically why shouldn't Fox be getting $5 a month. And I guess, you had incredible success with Idol in Season 8 or Season 9, and you obviously have gotten retrans. The cable operators seem increasingly willing to play ball on retrans in bigger and bigger ways. And I'm just wondering what are the issues? Is it regulatory? What stopped you from literally setting a hard level on something like $4 or $5 a month per sub for the FOX Network? How do you drive this far faster even than you are now, or why aren't you even just pushing it with an extra zero in front of it?

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess in some ways, Rome wasn't built in a day. But we have important relationships with distributors. I think we want to get a fair value for our content but I think, we, in all honesty, tried to approach this constructively. We built businesses with t
componenttext: I guess in some ways, Rome wasn't built in a day. But we have important relationships with distributors. I think we want to get a fair value for our content but I think, we, in all honesty, tried to approach this constructively. We built businesses with them. We built valuable cable channels. We feel we have enormous value in the FOX Network. We felt that the right thing to do was to try and take a big step forward to get the value of that FOX content recognized. Could you argue with we're significantly more? Sure, you could. But there are a lot of issues involved. Certainly, you did hear noise from an array of fronts. And I think you try to take all those factors in terms of the relationship we have with them in other businesses, the broader marketplace, and try and figure out how do you get this to get moving, and get this to a place that at least gets us started in terms of recognizing the fair value for the FOX Network. And it doesn't have a -- I think what we're trying not to do is have a relative difficult negotiation, a negotiation that was ultimately really disruptive to a point that fractured a lot of things in a way that it wasn't sort of respecting how do we continue to build the business with the distributors, as we have over the last x years.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I just like to add that the big cable companies are making really great operating profits. And what we're asking for, and even if our network competitors ask for the same and get the same, is certainly not going to kill the cable companies. I mean maybe 1
componenttext: I just like to add that the big cable companies are making really great operating profits. And what we're asking for, and even if our network competitors ask for the same and get the same, is certainly not going to kill the cable companies. I mean maybe 10% of their operating profits. We still have two or three years to pass through.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Rich, what you really should have, I think over time, we expect we should get a value that's reflective of the value of our content. I think it's a matter of how do you get there in a way that is, I guess, in the one-pedal people would call it ag
componenttext: I think, Rich, what you really should have, I think over time, we expect we should get a value that's reflective of the value of our content. I think it's a matter of how do you get there in a way that is, I guess, in the one-pedal people would call it aggressive and another level that we tried to be in a respect full of an array of fronts and relationships.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the deals you have outstanding, if this is the base line for your new contract strategy going forward, how many years before, is it a two-year process? Do you get 50% of it in the next 12 months and the other 50% thereafter? What's the, k
componenttext: When you look at the deals you have outstanding, if this is the base line for your new contract strategy going forward, how many years before, is it a two-year process? Do you get 50% of it in the next 12 months and the other 50% thereafter? What's the, kind of, the waterfall to get this to affect the vast majority of the country for you over the next few years?

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: As I said, it's sort of mixed. Again, the ones we deal directly with, we probably don't have quite. We have several major affiliates that are quite the visibility through the affiliate side of it. But I would guess, it's not dissimilar. It's sort of throu
componenttext: As I said, it's sort of mixed. Again, the ones we deal directly with, we probably don't have quite. We have several major affiliates that are quite the visibility through the affiliate side of it. But I would guess, it's not dissimilar. It's sort of through the ones we deal which triggers directly for three to four process. But probably in the next three years, about half of the sub-base, about half of the unit per sub.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you please talk about the view on the value of film libraries in current conditions? There are two reportedly for sale, MGM and Miramax. Are these still attractive and complementary assets for a major studio like News Corp? And secondly, cable network
componenttext: Can you please talk about the view on the value of film libraries in current conditions? There are two reportedly for sale, MGM and Miramax. Are these still attractive and complementary assets for a major studio like News Corp? And secondly, cable networks which is roughly half of your operating profit, the margins were 34% in this quarter operating profit, how should we think about long-term operating profit margins for this business?

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of film libraries...
componenttext: In terms of film libraries...

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: There are two questions, they're film libraries. Whatever you like it's just a matter of opinion what they were. The big one, MGM, is for the most part, very old. There has some good films in it. The right price would be interested, but it appears that th
componenttext: There are two questions, they're film libraries. Whatever you like it's just a matter of opinion what they were. The big one, MGM, is for the most part, very old. There has some good films in it. The right price would be interested, but it appears that there are more interested. So I think you can count us out of that one altogether. And we don't know how that will end up and, I guess, I can rule out Miramax right away.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I think terms of film libraries, again, I think there's certainly a value. You do have to look at DVD market that is in decline not growth, which was a significant part of it. The flip side of Television market frequently, overseas, is pretty healthy. But
componenttext: I think terms of film libraries, again, I think there's certainly a value. You do have to look at DVD market that is in decline not growth, which was a significant part of it. The flip side of Television market frequently, overseas, is pretty healthy. But the second issue on film libraries, realistically, you need that current product. It clearly reinvigorates if you just have a stay-all libraries that sits there, and gets stale over time. It's probably a depreciating asset. So I think it's important in a film library to have that current product flowing in that continues to give it a currency and liveliness to it. I think in terms of long-term cable, the long-term cable margins, I think we continue believe it, as we've got. We continue to drive in some ways, but their businesses is gets frequently, as you take global franchises, is that it probably have opportunities. I mean, as we had National Geographic, National Geographic Wild, the type of content that really travels around the world, I think, gives us an opportunity to really create value, very cost-efficiently and the like. So I think we feel good about where the cable business is and opportunities that we have to continue to drive those margins forward.

So we have up -- comparative to last year, we've got a big benefit in the first half on a comparison from the weak film business, first six months of fiscal '09.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the books business, obviously, there's been a bit of controversy over how Apple may price e-Books versus Amazon. So I was wondering if you could just share with us your perspective on retail and wholesale pricing for books in the digital delivery
componenttext: Just on the books business, obviously, there's been a bit of controversy over how Apple may price e-Books versus Amazon. So I was wondering if you could just share with us your perspective on retail and wholesale pricing for books in the digital delivery mode?

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: We don't like the Amazon model of selling everything at $9.99. They don't pay us that. We pay payers a full wholesale price of $14 or whatever we charge. We think it really devalues books and hurts all the retailers of the hardcover books. We're not again
componenttext: We don't like the Amazon model of selling everything at $9.99. They don't pay us that. We pay payers a full wholesale price of $14 or whatever we charge. We think it really devalues books and hurts all the retailers of the hardcover books. We're not against electronic books. On the contrary, we like them very much indeed. It's a low cost to us and so on, but we want some room to maneuver. And Apple, in its agreement with us, which has not been disclosed in detail, does allow for a variety of slightly higher prices. There will be prices very much less than the printed copies of books. But still, we'll not be fixed in a way that Amazon has been doing it. And payers at Amazon is now ready to sit down with us again and renegotiate pricing.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Before turning to the press inquiries, such we'll do next, I'd like to leave investors with a few closing comments. We obviously feel good about our second results and the momentum of our business for the rest of year with our fiscal 2010 guidance doublin
componenttext: Before turning to the press inquiries, such we'll do next, I'd like to leave investors with a few closing comments. We obviously feel good about our second results and the momentum of our business for the rest of year with our fiscal 2010 guidance doubling from a quarter ago. But with these results did not really reflect the degree to which our business are truly positioned grow over the next few years. And broadcasting as we touched on, we're now on track to build a dual-revenue stream business that enables FOX to achieve a value that equals its strength and its importance to viewers. Our leadership in content creation in both film and television, as Ruport say, continues to build as many of our competitors struggle in new technologies like 3D and mobile platforms, open up new avenues in revenue growth.At the same time, these new platforms and devices open up new avenues for our news, sports and print content. Our cable channels have great momentum both in the U.S. and overseas. In the U.S., we believe quality brands and content would be the real winners. In channels like FOX News and Nat Geo ideally position us. Internationally, we built a position of true leadership. We'll take advantage of the subscription in TV catches up with U.S. around the world. These businesses, as well as other unique franchises provide News Corp. a great opportunity, drive our profits and cash flow to a whole new level, as we grow beyond this year. Thank you and with that, I guess we will turn to the press.

headline: News Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, it will be very different ones. NBC problem was that their move from 10 to 11 reduced their lead-in to all their news services, which reduced the news service ratings, which in turn gave Conan a much worse lead-in than Leno's been getting. We d
componenttext: Certainly, it will be very different ones. NBC problem was that their move from 10 to 11 reduced their lead-in to all their news services, which reduced the news service ratings, which in turn gave Conan a much worse lead-in than Leno's been getting. We don't have that problem. On the other hand, all our affiliates tend to run syndicated programming from 11 to 11:30, most of them profitably. And it will take time to adjust. And if we would -- if we were to decide to go ahead and do it, and do it at 11:00 rather than 11:30 immediately, I am sure we have some difficult negotiations. But I'm speculating, we'll have to wait and see.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. And welcome to the News Corp. Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn the conference over to Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, News Corp., Reed Nolte. Please go ahead.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter fiscal 2010 earnings conference call. On the call today are Rupert Murdoch, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dave
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter fiscal 2010 earnings conference call. On the call today are Rupert Murdoch, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dave DeVoe, our Chief Financial Officer. Dave will give a detailed presentation of the quarter results, followed by Rupert who will give his own perspective and color on the quarter. We'll then take your question, first from the financial community and then from the press.
This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to News Corporation's business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. News Corporation's Form 10-Q for the three months ended December 31, 2009, identifies the risks and opportunities that could cause actual results to differ. And these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filing. Additionally, this call includes certain non-GAAP financial measure. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found on our earnings release in our 10-Q filing. And with that, I'll turn it over to Dave.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Reed, thank you and good afternoon, everybody. As you all seen in today's earnings release, we're very pleased with the financial results of the third quarter of fiscal 2010. Revenues grew 19% over the third quarter a year ago, with increases in all of ou
componenttext:
Reed, thank you and good afternoon, everybody. As you all seen in today's earnings release, we're very pleased with the financial results of the third quarter of fiscal 2010. Revenues grew 19% over the third quarter a year ago, with increases in all of our major segments led by double-digit increases in our Filmed Entertainment, Cable Networks, Newspapers and Book Publishing segments. 
Fueled by this top line growth and benefiting from our cost reduction efforts, segment operating income exceeded $1.25 billion, an improvement of 55% from a year ago. This growth rises to 67% after considering the absence of NDS results from this year. 
Net income in the quarter was $839 million with earnings per share of $0.32. This compares to last year's third quarter's net income of $2.7 billion or $1.04 a share. And as a reminder, the year ago quarter included a one-time items of $1.1 billion in after-tax income or $0.43 a share. This largely reflects the gain on the NDS transaction, as well a one-time non-cash tax benefit of $1.2 billion or $0.46 a share.
Included in this year's results are one-time items netting to after-tax income of $79 million or $0.03 a share and this is primarily related to News Corporation's share of BSkyB's gain on their partial sale of ITV, and a tax benefit associated with an asset sale. 
And looking at our businesses this quarter, clearly the standout performances were from our Cable and Filmed segments, which together delivered nearly $1.1 billion of the company's operating profit.
At our Cable Networks, we continue to deliver solid growth with operating income contributions up 38%, on 16% higher revenues. Overall affiliate fees increased 16% from growth across all the channels and advertising revenues were up 19%, reflecting the strength of FOX News in our International Cable businesses. 
Our Cable Networks now account for nearly 50% of our operating income. And we expect this percentage to continue to increase. The primary drivers behind the year-over-year increases were from the FOX News Channel, which achieved its highest ever quarterly profit due to strong affiliate fees and advertising increases.  The March quarter was the channel's highest rated quarter in the network history in terms of total viewers. 
At this point, we have renegotiated all the original carriage deals with major cable and satellite distributors that were made at the launch. And renewals will begin again at the end of this calendar year.
Our Regional Sports Networks has also generated higher profit contributions driven by double-digit affiliate revenue increases. The advertising revenues were up only slightly in the March quarter which was adversely impacted by the NHL Olympic break. More recent trends suggest the advertising and local sports are starting to follow the upswing we are seeing at our local broadcast Television stations. 
The Fox International Channel has also reported a 48% profit increase on strong advertising and affiliate revenue growth, particularly in Europe and Asia. 
And finally, at our STAR businesses. In India and Greater China are showing renewed strength with higher profit contribution supported by advertising increases. STAR Plus and India has regained its leadership position in ratings and the strength of our Bengali regional channels and South Indian channels continue to drive higher revenues and profits.
At our Filmed segment, third quarter operating income was a record $497 million, up $215 million or 76% over last year's result. This strong performance was very much driven by the phenomenal success of Avatar, with over $2.7 billion in worldwide box office receipts. The quarter also benefited from the theatrical success of Alvin and the Chipmunks 2, as well as continued strong home entertainment performances from Ice Age, X-Men, and Night at the Museum 2.
Turning to our Pay Television business. SKY Italia, SKY generated segment operating income of $35 million as compared to $63 million in the third quarter a year ago, reflecting the continued challenging business and economic environment in Italy. While SKY Italia's financial results are clearly not as strong as we like to report, we continue to remain very confident in the local growth of this profitable business in this under-penetrated market. 
Total revenues at SKY declined 3% in local currency terms as compared to the prior quarter, largely reflecting a fewer average subscribers and flat ARPU in the quarter compared to a year ago. Overall cost were flat as higher sports-related costs were offset by savings and other programming and subscriber acquisition costs. SKY Italia subscriber base declined by 39,000 compared with the previous quarter end as total quarterly gross additions of 118,000 were more than offset by churn.
SKY's total subscriber count at end of quarter was 4.7 million subscribers. At the end of the March quarter, over 2.4 million subscribers representing approximately 54% of the subscriber base were taking an HD or PVR premium service compared with approximately 26% of the base a year ago. 
As a result of the growth in these premium services, we've begun to see some improvement in the overall churn rate. And currently, the annual churn rate is expected to be approximately 13%, which is consistent with the prior year. We expect the upcoming World Cup broadcast in June, as well as increased adoption of premium services will help stabilize churn and return SKY to growing subscribers.
Our Television segment generated operating income in the quarter of $40 million as compared to $9 million reported in the third quarter a year ago. This $30 million improvement was driven by strong revenue growth at our Television Stations, partially offset by increased losses at the broadcast network from lower ratings. 
Station revenues were up 18% on the quarter compared to a year ago, reflecting improved local advertising trends, particularly in the automotive and telecommunications sectors. As a result of the cost containment initiatives at the stations, their entire revenue increased was converted to increased earnings.
Shifting to Newspapers and Information Services. Operating income in this sector -- this year's quarter was $131 million. This is up nearly fivefold from $29 million reported a year ago. The substantial improvement is largely driven by higher advertising across all our markets and lower operating expenses throughout all our Newspaper businesses. 
Ad growth to The Wall Street Journal was approximately 25%, while our U.K. titles in local currency revenues increased by nearly 10%. Our Newspaper results also benefited from favorable foreign exchange impact of nearly $30 million related to the strengthening of the Australian dollar against the U.S. dollar. 
And at our Other segment, we reported a third-quarter operating loss of $150 million as compared to a loss of $88 million a year ago. The $62 million increase primarily reflects the absence of NDS' operating profits this year due to its partial sale in early February of 2009. The third quarter of year ago including $60 million in NDS operating income. Additionally, the Digital Media group reported higher losses principally from lower search and advertising revenues, offset in part by cost reductions from our recent restructuring.
And before I address our guidance, I just like to make a couple of comments related to our balance sheet. Our gross debt balance at the end of March quarter was $13.5 billion, a reduction of nearly $1.8 billion from the prior quarter. Our cash balance at quarter end was nearly $8.2 billion, an increase of over $900 million. These balance is taken into account the receipt of $900 million of the Dow Jones Index-related transactions, the redemption of substantially all-of-the-box exchangeable securities at $1.6 billion outflow, the maturity and repayment of $150 million senior note and approximately $2.1 billion in cash flow from operations less CapEx in the quarter. 
Note that this very high cash flow from operations includes the receipt of the majority of Avatar's box office revenues. A sizable portion of which will be paid to third-party participants on the film in this current June quarter.
Our strong free cash flow generation in conjunction with asset sales has led to the buildup of significant cash balances. We are well aware of the resulting inefficient capital structure and are evaluating options for the best use of our surplus cash. This is an important area of focus for us and our Board of Directors as we proceed to our fiscal year 2011 budget process, which is currently underway. We intend to revise guidance on this issue by our next earnings call.
And finally, let me address our earnings guidance for the remainder of fiscal 2010. As a reminder, we measure this guidance, excluding from the fiscal 2009 segment operating income results, the $121 million in operating profit from NDF [ph](18:16) which is no longer consolidated in our results. So as we look at measuring growth in fiscal 2010, we are comparing it to a base of $3.44 billion in segment operating profit for fiscal 2009. 
In early February, we gave guidance anticipating our operating income growth rate for fiscal 2010 to be in the low 20% range, above the $3.44 billion fiscal 2009 adjusted result. Although we have performed better than anticipated in several of our businesses resulting in the 42% growth rate we just reported for the first nine months, we are currently forecasting our fourth quarter results to be down from a year ago. 
The primary reason for this is that despite the solid home entertainment performance forecasted for Avatar, we are expecting the Filmed segment to be down approximately $100 million from last year, principally due to year-over-year timing of releases. 
Last year's very strong results included a significant number of home entertainment in free and paid TV releases. And also this year, we are expecting slightly higher releasing cost for our June releases. In addition, we are projecting lower results at FBC due to higher programming costs, lower network revenues and higher marketing in support of our summer schedule. 
As a result, taking all these items into account and excluding the effect to the prior year's Valassis litigation settlement, we are increasing our operating income guidance to a growth rate of in the high 20% range above the fiscal 2009 adjusted results. 
I think it's important to underscore that this upcoming fourth quarter comparison is not at all indicative of the overall growth momentum of our businesses. While it's premature to get into a discussion around the guidance for our net fiscal year, we feel very good about the continued growth momentum for the company as we look to 2011. With that, I'd now like to turn the call over to Rupert for his comments.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. David just reviewed with you, we had really exceptional results in this last quarter, pretty much across the board. We do feel good, not just about this quarter but about the rest of the year and bey
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. David just reviewed with you, we had really exceptional results in this last quarter, pretty much across the board. We do feel good, not just about this quarter but about the rest of the year and beyond. And I think it's for five reasons. 
First is the primacy of our content. On this call, last quarter, I spent a lot of time discussing the value of content and the crucial role of content place in the future of our company. Our results this past quarter continue to bear that out. Content is driving our outstanding performance, from the history-making film Avatar to the unstoppable FOX News Channel, to our popular regional sports channels, to new hit chart like Glee and Modern Family. The growth at our flagship newspapers and international channels. 
Fortune favors the bold. From the every rated media [ph](21:31) our approach to opponent is setting new standards to success and redefining the industry. In film, Avatar is not only number one, it is redefined 3D. In Television, to the number one entertainment network, we have the number one news network. Something we would tell was impossible. And with the line used to be division, is only 17% of our total business. We have the number one national paper on all three continents. 
The second reason I'm confident about our future, is that we continue to extend our core businesses in innovative ways. New technologies like 3D and mobile platforms are opening up new avenues for real revenue growth. Just last month, Apple introduced its iPad, which I believe will lead a revolution in media consumption and create added value for both our news and entertainment content.
And I said last time, these new digital devices are entirely dependent on the flow of high-quality content, the business we are in. We're uniquely poised to capitalize on this proliferation, which is providing another revenue stream for publishers and studios. The news, for example, we live in a world with a consumption adjournment has never been greater. By taking advantage of innovations such as the iPad, we are now delivering first-rate journalism in ways that cater to a new generation of consumers. A generation that relies on digital devices for professional and personal use. 
And just the first month alone, we have more than 64,000 active users for the WSJ iPad app, and I'm not kindle. We keep a 100% of the subscriber revenue with the iPad. Today, we are in final discussions with a number of publishers, device makers and technology companies, and we will assume develop an innovative subscription model that will deliver digital content to consumers, wherever and whenever they want it. 
In a couple of weeks ago, for example, FOX led a consortium of American Broadcast Groups, and announced a joint venture, one that will develop a new national mobile content service using broadcast spectrum we already owned. It could prove a financial boom to companies like us, with the wealth of valuable local and national news content.
The third reason I'm bullish on News Corporations future is that our core businesses are strongly positioned to grow for the foreseeable future. In Broadcasting, we're now on track to build a jewel revenue on stream that enables FOX to achieve real value. One that equals the strength and importance to viewers. And we will continue to innovate hard [ph](24:39) with all our distribution partners to ensure we remain on this track. Retransmission is a real breakthrough. 
In Cable, our channels are young. They have great momentum and plenty of room for growth, both in the United States and internationally. This business accounts now for about half of our total company's earnings. 
In the U.S., we are leading a competition, we call it quality brands, like FOX News, FOX Business, FX and NatGeo. And internationally, we have put a position of true leadership with FOX International Channels, one that will only continue to strengthen as multichannel subscription TV around the world catches up with the U.S. 
 
Finally, we continue to sharpen our focus by divesting non-core businesses, like bTV, say, Balkan's TV and the Dow Jones index business, while further investing in businesses in regions with high growth potential, such as Germany and the Middle East. 
Let me close by saying that in the ad markets, we are currently seeing strong across-the-board growth, particularly in the U.S. and Britain. That bodes well for many of our core businesses. We're optimistic about the trends we're seeing. We're even more optimistic about the clear momentum in our businesses, which will indicate our strategy and build greater shareholder value. So thank you very much, and we'll be happy to answer your questions.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Doug Mitchelson with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Doug Mitchelson with Deutsche Bank.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question for Rupert and Chase. Including fiscal year '10, seven in the last 10 years, News Corp. put up double-digit EBIT growth, and two of those three years that you did not were recession years and the other was 8% growth. So I think, as we lo
componenttext: I have a question for Rupert and Chase. Including fiscal year '10, seven in the last 10 years, News Corp. put up double-digit EBIT growth, and two of those three years that you did not were recession years and the other was 8% growth. So I think, as we look forward to 2011, there's a lot of concern among investors, you're not going to be able to keep up the same strong growth pace that you delivered last decade, partly due to tough film comps. So my question is, do you believe strong growth will continue in fiscal '11? And if so, what gives you that confidence?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, but not 67%. And how strong? Will they be in single digits or double digits? I don't know. A lot of it's in timing on the films. We have, as a matter of fact, a great slate of films coming up, but we don't have an Avatar in there. But tha
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, but not 67%. And how strong? Will they be in single digits or double digits? I don't know. A lot of it's in timing on the films. We have, as a matter of fact, a great slate of films coming up, but we don't have an Avatar in there. But that will be more than compensated for by the outstanding growth, which is guaranteed in our cable channels. So if this present growth in advertising, that's very evident at the moment, continues, I think we can be very confident.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I guess to add to that, probably in the Film segment, we delivered tough comparison because of Avatar [indiscernible] (28:04) really across the rest of the business. And certainly, the Cable business continues to have great momentum. You see
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I guess to add to that, probably in the Film segment, we delivered tough comparison because of Avatar [indiscernible] (28:04) really across the rest of the business. And certainly, the Cable business continues to have great momentum. You see it in the numbers, and there's really no reason we don't continue to build on that. If anything, you've got sort of an ad market that is even picking up. And so, when you look at some of the sports businesses, it's probably been up a little slower than others, in terms of the ad markets shaking up and they're now seeing a pickup. I think the Station business, actually, currently has some favorable comparisons. When you look at the first half of last year, some benefits there. So I think we look at those, and since we got an ad market out there, they're really, right now, on almost every level. It looks great and it continues to be a strong scatter market, on both the Cable and Broadcast side. You continue to have sort of, really, competition you haven't seen for a while in key sectors of the ad market, whether it's auto, it's for retail, or telecom, consumer electronics. Again, I think we get some benefits from the Newspapers side, with comparisons against a year ago and sort of expect to continue to see the momentum there. So it is a set of businesses that I think we feel pretty good about. And as you look at something like the Broadcast business, retrans [retransmission] is clearly just going to continue to build, as more players come up and we move through the next few years. So that will clearly be helping both the stations and the network, so -- and then, we think we got the momentum to the majority of our businesses.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I can answer that if you like. And just to say that we're well aware that our balance sheet, as Dave said, has limitations at the moment, given the amount of cash we have. We're looking at all our options to make best use of this cash and expect to take a
componenttext: I can answer that if you like. And just to say that we're well aware that our balance sheet, as Dave said, has limitations at the moment, given the amount of cash we have. We're looking at all our options to make best use of this cash and expect to take actions within the next three months. Options available to us include: increased dividends, stock buybacks, debt repayments and investing in our businesses, and always opportunistic to make accretive investments that generate a good return for shareholders. I think we have not done this in the last year because we've been nervously on top of the world economy. Wherever we looked, it looked pretty fragile, and now there is a growing air of confidence. So we'll see. But if the opportunities that arise in the way that we expect to in the next few months, we will do something else.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
