componenttext: That question comes from the line of David Bank with RBC Capital.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color, in terms of the near-term momentum, particularly in local TV and newspaper, characterized stations in local TV and newspaper. And then more specifically, in the press release, you talked about aut
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color, in terms of the near-term momentum, particularly in local TV and newspaper, characterized stations in local TV and newspaper. And then more specifically, in the press release, you talked about auto and telecom being the standout categories. Auto has been a big driver. Are you starting to see a kind of a broader recovery in more categories' difference between first calendar quarter and second calendar quarter?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, first, I think, in terms of momentum, I think the Station business for the quarter we're in is sort of in the mid-20s. I think, even plus that, as we go through the quarter. So it's certainly, probably stronger than it's been, if anything. An
componenttext: Yes. I mean, first, I think, in terms of momentum, I think the Station business for the quarter we're in is sort of in the mid-20s. I think, even plus that, as we go through the quarter. So it's certainly, probably stronger than it's been, if anything. And it really is a broad based -- I mean, at this point, really pretty much than in most categories. So it's not just auto and telecom. I mean, again, if you look at the retail sector, you'll look at stuff -- even the financial sector, which people have talked about, and you've got nice competition in the insurance space. So it's pretty broad. And again, provides pretty healthy dynamics. Now pharmaceutical sector does not want that one where that begin to. And maybe not all of them, but I'd say it's a broad healthy market with anything, sort of, I think, people feeling there's more competition for market share and awareness that if you want to try and be in the game and you want to build the brand, you've got market it. And I think television, in particular, has once again sort of proven the test of time that, as much as we're ready, we sort of want some of these other new mediums to emerge. The power of television advertising is second to none. But it really is -- it is certainly not driven by a couple of factors. It's a broad, healthy market right now.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll just add to that. I think we're seeing pretty optimistic and expanded advertising budgets from the big advertisers. When that money will drop, whether it will be in our first fiscal quarter or the second one, I would be inclined to bet that it'd be m
componenttext: I'll just add to that. I think we're seeing pretty optimistic and expanded advertising budgets from the big advertisers. When that money will drop, whether it will be in our first fiscal quarter or the second one, I would be inclined to bet that it'd be more in the second one, when they're launching all their new car models. But there's a lot of money out there on the boards, and our advertising people are really, really optimistic so I'd be [ph] upfront on the network. And although we get a higher cost per thousand, as pretty [ph] over the year, audiences shrink and ours were shrunk much less than anybody else's, that money is finding it's way across into the cable networks. And people now, more and more, they do their own networking, they've all got a DVR. And those shows any sort of a rating can attract that good advertising. So it feels good. That's all I'm saying.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Jessica Reif-Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Jessica Reif-Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that you mentioned that the FOX News affiliate agreements are coming up at the end of this calendar year. I was wondering -- you had very strong increases in the last go-round. I was wondering if you could kind of frame for us how you're thinking
componenttext: I think that you mentioned that the FOX News affiliate agreements are coming up at the end of this calendar year. I was wondering -- you had very strong increases in the last go-round. I was wondering if you could kind of frame for us how you're thinking about the next round of negotiations. And then separately, if there was any weak link and all in the quarter, it was SKY Italia. I'm just wondering if you could talk about plans over the next few years to drive penetration in that market?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, I mean, first, in FOX News, I think what we said is they start to come up. They obviously like come up over time, so it's not one fell swoop. So they began, but it'll be a number of years, over which agreements come up. And I'm not going to
componenttext: Yes. I think, I mean, first, in FOX News, I think what we said is they start to come up. They obviously like come up over time, so it's not one fell swoop. So they began, but it'll be a number of years, over which agreements come up. And I'm not going to get too specific and sort of can't make [ph] (35:34) -- I think you should ask negotiations in private, not in public. So I'm probably not going to sort of put out there any specifics on what our expectations, other than look at, I think, the FOX News Network and the power and importance of it is certainly, maybe with the FBN, second to none. I mean, I think it is a channel that has built an enormous following and enormous audience. It's  tremendously important to some kind of a major segment [ph] (35:59) of the country out there, and heading into a complicated political arena that probably gets more complicated as you go between now and 2012. I think the importance of that channel and the value of that channel probably has never been higher. And what we're going to do is get fair value for that channel. So certainly, they will pursue that appropriately and practically.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of SKY Italia, it probably is somewhat what we talked about a quarter ago. I mean, SKY Italia, since the -- and beginning middle of last year, it's clearly gone through a tough stretch. The economy actually continues to be tough. But I think more
componenttext: In terms of SKY Italia, it probably is somewhat what we talked about a quarter ago. I mean, SKY Italia, since the -- and beginning middle of last year, it's clearly gone through a tough stretch. The economy actually continues to be tough. But I think more so, it had a number of factors. Probably, I think, the biggest one being the tax that was thrown at it and we've largely digested that, and now, it's sort of renewals in a more ordinary rate. We had to restructure sales because media sets pulled the ability to advertise on TV. We got a competitor we didn't have, which is okay, but it's better we had some short-term advantages, in terms of cost and programming like sports. So we digested those. Maybe we digested those reasonably well. We've invested in building a foundation. I guess, really, I'd say, initially, foundation for long-term growth. And we really do think this is a great long-term play and that's about making sure we're the quality player there, clearly investing in HD and DVR technology. I think -- and that's still happening. We're going to ramp up to that 30 HD channels in the next month or so. We were only about 10 in the beginning of this year. I think we've got about a third of our customers now have HD. So that's come out. I think, actually over half our customers have HD and DVR, on second thought. So the quality installation in the home is growing. And again, that's not going to pay off in a quarter. That's going to pay off over time, as you build behind that. We overhauled our packages to be more aggressive in the market. So I actually think we've done a good job building a foundation. And I think our priority, if you look in the short term, the next year, really should be on re-energizing momentum, from a subscriber perspective, into the business. And I think that's where -- and that's what I guess I would say, it's really where our focus should be. I think, obviously, that's both churn in sales, I think as Dave touched on. We've already started to make some headline in churn. And as we guide to the tax and the like, I think we'll make further headlines. I think on the sales side we've got some momentum to that. We've got some events that'll help us. I think the HD and DVR, again, had incremental traction. I think our sales organization is sort of reorganized up big years to selling without reliance on TV advertising that they've had in the past, and are getting much better at doing that. So I think we feel very good about our competitive position. Clearly, some of the regulatory issues that reside under our -- changed the end of next year. And we feel it. We think there'll be competition there, but we think we have a great proposition with the quality offerings that really doesn't have a peer on that market that really, still is in the early stages of its growth. Again, I think our short-term focus should be on driving that business forward, in terms of subscribers. And I think profitability will follow behind it, in volume [ph] (39:26), and I still expect this to be a great business for us.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Adam Alexander with JBWere.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Adam Alexander with JBWere.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to touch on a couple of the associates, which look I think, big drivers of EPS growth in the next couple of years. First one, Sky D. Chase, could you just give us an update on your initial thoughts to that business now you've become the Chairm
componenttext: I just want to touch on a couple of the associates, which look I think, big drivers of EPS growth in the next couple of years. First one, Sky D. Chase, could you just give us an update on your initial thoughts to that business now you've become the Chairman there? And then on BSkyB, it delivered another great result last week. The business looks in fantastic shape. Do you think News Corp. would get greater recognition of the strength of that business if it was consolidated?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think in Sky Deutschland, I mean, I think they announced earnings next week. So I'd probably not going to get too far in front of their announcement. Sky Deutschland, they haven't been in as long as Italy. And probably, in some ways, some of the thi
componenttext: And I think in Sky Deutschland, I mean, I think they announced earnings next week. So I'd probably not going to get too far in front of their announcement. Sky Deutschland, they haven't been in as long as Italy. And probably, in some ways, some of the things you just said are kind of true there, though at an early stage. We've got some new management there, which I think we're very excited about, bringing some of the expertise from BSkyB to, and into Germany and Brian Sullivan. We've made some of the moves in HD and DVRs that were just right now, putting out the HD DVR box. We maybe just, more recently, overhaul the program packaging and the branding there. And it's a different market. Obviously, with cable and sort of the dual distribution to cable and up cable and satellite. And so it's not just a calling of the others, but -- and then we've taken a lot of steps, so as to put it on better footing, as clearly a work in progress. There's no two ways about that. Above all [ph] (41:02), Germany is a great market. I mean, I was just there for a meeting I've been to, and you can't help but be -- it's about the rest there [ph]  (41:10), you can't help but be impressed about Germany. And I think there is a great momentum to that. A great opportunity to really build a really unique, strong business. It'll take time. It is not a 12-month plan. This is a plan to build over time. I do believe that as we build on those strengths and really get traction in things like HD, and get the right technology, in terms of set top boxes and get an organization that continues to grow in expertise and strength, in terms of selling and servicing that business. We are, again, still building some of that foundation. But I think we've got it going in the right direction, but clearly, not minimizing. The work is in front of us, but I think, equally not minimizing, I think, the opportunity in front of us, with a country like Germany. At Sky -- I mean, Sky is a great business. And I admire them for the strength they've built. And we've been a happy shareholder for 15 years. We are controlling shareholder, and I think happy and comfortable with the shareholding we have.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And that question comes from the line of Jason Bazinet with Citi.
componenttext: And that question comes from the line of Jason Bazinet with Citi.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of folks on the buy set are looking at the acceleration of Netflix results with great interest. And I was just wondering, as you watch that business evolve, do you look at that as a good news story because it's an effective way to monetize s
componenttext: I think a lot of folks on the buy set are looking at the acceleration of Netflix results with great interest. And I was just wondering, as you watch that business evolve, do you look at that as a good news story because it's an effective way to monetize sort of the older content within your library? Or do you look at it potentially as an opportunity to monetize your library in a better way, maybe better than you are today? And how might the industry sort of change or evolve, do you think, over the next, call it, two to three years, if at all?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably something we need to continue evaluate. So I wouldn't probably, at this point, come down clearly on either side. I think we look at it as important for us to continuing on. It's one of the greatest things of being content owners, it'
componenttext: I think it's probably something we need to continue evaluate. So I wouldn't probably, at this point, come down clearly on either side. I think we look at it as important for us to continuing on. It's one of the greatest things of being content owners, it's the ability to develop different windows and different ways to monetize our product and provide products to consumers in interesting ways, in interesting shapes and forms. I think there is a question whether the Netflix model is getting us fair value for our product, and I think that's a question we need to continue to evaluate and perhaps taken some steps, in terms of already moving windows, with some players on some of the newer releases. And like I think, as digital evolves, as VOD evolves, these windows are clearly continually evolving business. And we need to continue to study it and get smarter about it, and make sure we're getting the value we should be getting for our products and not having our product undervalued or devalued as it becomes available in the marketplace. So I think it's a focus, and something that I think you'll see continue to evolve as we go through the next few years.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: That question comes from the line of Tuna Amobi with Standard & Poor's.
componenttext: That question comes from the line of Tuna Amobi with Standard & Poor's.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: So my question is on the FOX Audience Network. I wanted to get a little bit more strategic clarity regarding FOX Audience, particularly with the MySpace deal with Google, I believe, expiring sometime this summer. So just any color on how that unit could r
componenttext: So my question is on the FOX Audience Network. I wanted to get a little bit more strategic clarity regarding FOX Audience, particularly with the MySpace deal with Google, I believe, expiring sometime this summer. So just any color on how that unit could restart. Perhaps recap the lines itself. I know there's been some suggestion that some of that may, in fact, be spun off to maybe some private holders to be able to attack the display advertising market more efficiently. So what's your thinking around that asset, and how you can perhaps position yourself to monetize it better, particularly with the Google deal coming due?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure the Google deal has a real impact on FAN. I mean, in sort of the sale, in sort of different segments of the digital arena. But I mean, with FAN, I think the guys FAN have done a great job building a very effective, efficient ad sales business
componenttext: I'm not sure the Google deal has a real impact on FAN. I mean, in sort of the sale, in sort of different segments of the digital arena. But I mean, with FAN, I think the guys FAN have done a great job building a very effective, efficient ad sales business there. I'm not going to comment on any of the rumors that are out there. I don't think it's productive but -- I think the goal is to go to business and it's a challenge for them. And the key is attract enough traffic to make it a profitable business. So I don't think there's any -- for the ad side, I don't think there's any rocket science, but it doesn't really get affected by Google, which is really the search side of the MySpace business, so -- and with that, we will deal with. But FAN, I think they've done a really good job building a very effective, and I think, actually, quite competitive and uniquely strong operation there. And key is to build enough traffic to...

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: So if I can refer to the question a little bit, do you feel that then the structure that you have in place today in terms of the strategic set up and not so much the organizational structure, do you feel that it's kind of optimal in this environment? Or a
componenttext: So if I can refer to the question a little bit, do you feel that then the structure that you have in place today in terms of the strategic set up and not so much the organizational structure, do you feel that it's kind of optimal in this environment? Or are there plans as you restructure that asset to perhaps do some kind of strategic shuffle that could affect its structure within News Corp. is what I'm getting at.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think the fact is that it's now become the leading music site. And we've got to admit that in the last two or three years, I think we made some big mistakes, but we've got a fine new management now. We've started to introduce new features. There'd b
componenttext: No, I think the fact is that it's now become the leading music site. And we've got to admit that in the last two or three years, I think we made some big mistakes, but we've got a fine new management now. We've started to introduce new features. There'd be a lot of changes coming to this summer. And we're going to judge it at the end of this year. I mean the early indications, and there are early indications that we're getting more visitors and is staying longer, but it's -- and when that gets more substantial, we'll get more advertising.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: On the guidance for the, effectively, the fourth quarter, Dave, you mentioned Filmed would be down, I think, about $100 million; mentioned Fox Networks. Anything else that you highlight on a year-on-year comp basis that is working against you? I'm thinkin
componenttext: On the guidance for the, effectively, the fourth quarter, Dave, you mentioned Filmed would be down, I think, about $100 million; mentioned Fox Networks. Anything else that you highlight on a year-on-year comp basis that is working against you? I'm thinking maybe Cable Networks might be one where you've started to lap the affiliate fee increases at FOX News.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our Cable Networks, I think, needed to grow not only this quarter but for the foreseeable future. Those are the two principal operating units that created the down for the quarter.
componenttext: Well, our Cable Networks, I think, needed to grow not only this quarter but for the foreseeable future. Those are the two principal operating units that created the down for the quarter.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just say on the future, these Cable Networks, which Chase has referred to, at least in the next year or two, we can see the growth is coming just on the existing contracts that we have. So we're really in very good shape there, unless there's some
componenttext: I would just say on the future, these Cable Networks, which Chase has referred to, at least in the next year or two, we can see the growth is coming just on the existing contracts that we have. So we're really in very good shape there, unless there's some terrible downturn in advertising. The Cable side seems fine. On the Filmed side, we've got a really great slate of films coming up for the next 12 months, perhaps three big films we have for the summer. I mean they're not Iron Man or Toy Story, but they're very commercial and strong. But they will be costing us real money in this quarter. Just as in the second quarter, we booked a loss for Avatar, and there'll be a loss this time on a team [ph]. And there's a new picture with Tom Cruise coming on July the 4th weekend. And then we've got very strong films coming after that, Wall Street in September, and a great Thanksgiving and Christmas schedule. And we're feeling -- it all looks pretty good, and we even have the outlines now of a good schedule right through next summer. So as I said, we haven't gotten Avatar that's going to make us $400 million, but we have a plenty of pictures there that have got a lot of upside to them.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I may have stated the obvious, but I actually just want to add on to what Rupert said. I mean the Filmed business, obviously, is one that doesn't have a sort of quarter-to-quarter steady state, but we have a fabulous team in the Filmed business t
componenttext: Yes, and I may have stated the obvious, but I actually just want to add on to what Rupert said. I mean the Filmed business, obviously, is one that doesn't have a sort of quarter-to-quarter steady state, but we have a fabulous team in the Filmed business that is, I think, second to none. As Rupert said, we've got a fabulous slate of -- great slate of films. We're looking Christmas, fall, summer, even into the next animated picture next spring. So there are always timings in a quarter that can affect short term, but we have a great team there that does a great job, and we couldn't be more excited and positive about the Filmed business.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And then the Filmed financiers we have as partners in a lot of films, they do that broadest [ph] media. They all say that we operate in about 20% more economically than any of our competitors, except perhaps we're equal in the marketing costs.
componenttext: And then the Filmed financiers we have as partners in a lot of films, they do that broadest [ph] media. They all say that we operate in about 20% more economically than any of our competitors, except perhaps we're equal in the marketing costs.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: My question is actually on the Filmed business. Rupert, you talked about this, to review, of how you want to allocate capital. You have a tremendous team in place, and you've had a tremendous track record in Filmed. Are there things out there in the marke
componenttext: My question is actually on the Filmed business. Rupert, you talked about this, to review, of how you want to allocate capital. You have a tremendous team in place, and you've had a tremendous track record in Filmed. Are there things out there in the marketplace, either other studios or libraries -- you are in the Distribution business today with MGM. I think they're currently on the block. Is there anything you would look at on the Filmed side across the board, where you want to invest to acquire assets in that business?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we could be tempted if something real came on the market, but we don't consider MGM in that class, certainly, not at the price that they're talking. You have to be careful, two studios may turn into just 1 1/5. So I think we're better doing everythin
componenttext: Yes, we could be tempted if something real came on the market, but we don't consider MGM in that class, certainly, not at the price that they're talking. You have to be careful, two studios may turn into just 1 1/5. So I think we're better doing everything we can to expand Fox Film and Fox Television Production. There is a lot of money in making successful television programs. And now the one that are successful are certainly a minority. But in our case, the profits they make certainly make up for their failures and their write-offs. I mean the two big new shows this year are both made by us. Glee, which is on FBC, and Modern Family, which is a big hit on ABC. So overall [ph] show, particularly Modern Family, great revenue flows over the future years.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente with Barclays Capital.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple for Chase. Chase, first, I was hoping you could just update on any potential path towards profitability at your Digital Media Group, maybe quantify, as part of that, the step-down that you have at the end of this year contractually from Goog
componenttext: Just a couple for Chase. Chase, first, I was hoping you could just update on any potential path towards profitability at your Digital Media Group, maybe quantify, as part of that, the step-down that you have at the end of this year contractually from Google Search revenue. And then secondly, I thought maybe you could also talk a little bit about the relationship that the Network has with your non-owned TV station affiliates and the chance that you might start to get compensation from those affiliates that are accruing retransmission fees.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean on MySpace, Rupert touched on it. Clearly, MySpace is a work in progress. And we've made a number of changes. I think actually the team that we've put in place is doing some really good things. I mean actually some of them, we've had some rece
componenttext: Yes, I mean on MySpace, Rupert touched on it. Clearly, MySpace is a work in progress. And we've made a number of changes. I think actually the team that we've put in place is doing some really good things. I mean actually some of them, we've had some recent launches. Just last week or so, we had a tryout for Glee. They got, I think, 28,000 auditions for that and 80-something million votes about it, so. I think again, it speaks to the power of that platform and the restep [ph] platform still has. We got a lot of enhancements. We've improved the platform, made it a better customer experience. We got a lot of enhancements we're launching over the next couple of quarters. And clearly, our goal is to really build, to put in place this year, by the end of the calendar year, that business and create a foundation we can go forward with, and really a foundation that we can look to and start to drive as a cash-positive business going into 2011, and I think that's our goal. I think our focus this year is really more on improving the customer experience and creating a site that has growth. I mean if you look at some of the key numbers in terms of traffic and things like that, the trends are better, but they're not what they need to be. So we're still in -- or a number of the key metrics are not going up, but they're better than they were. And I think in the remainder of the year, we need to turn that. So as we get to the end of the year, we've got a lot of those metrics going in the right way and a business that we can look confidently end of the day, and it will be a good solid business for us. That's the goal this year, and that's we're looking to get to. What's the other business? The...

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The other question was just on non-owned affiliates and your pace and progress towards getting a payment or push for the retrans fees that they're accruing?
componenttext: The other question was just on non-owned affiliates and your pace and progress towards getting a payment or push for the retrans fees that they're accruing?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: There are discussions, so I'm not going to -- look, we clearly view the Network as the driving program out there for us and our affiliates, and we think it's important for us to retransmission to receive appropriate compensation for the Network Programmin
componenttext: There are discussions, so I'm not going to -- look, we clearly view the Network as the driving program out there for us and our affiliates, and we think it's important for us to retransmission to receive appropriate compensation for the Network Programming. And I think really we have a pretty good sense. When you go out, cable or satellite or telco provider, what is the programming they're paying for? I think programming is on top of that list, and trying to be argumentative is the NFL or the American Idol and the World Series and House. So I think it's important for us to be investing [ph]...

componenttext: And Glee.

componenttext: And Glee. We invested a lot in those shows, and it's worthy for us to get a fair compensation...

componenttext: No, we are not getting a -- we are in discussions with the affiliates now.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I had a quick query and it was considering the Television revenues, which if we listen to the commentary during the quarter, were up to 20%, 25%. And yet when we look at the TV numbers, they were in from $1.15 billion to $1.16 billion. And I was just curi
componenttext: I had a quick query and it was considering the Television revenues, which if we listen to the commentary during the quarter, were up to 20%, 25%. And yet when we look at the TV numbers, they were in from $1.15 billion to $1.16 billion. And I was just curious to know why that 20% growth at that station group didn't turn into larger growth at the overall Television segment?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: It's principally related to the Entertainment segment. Our range are down at the Entertainment.
componenttext: It's principally related to the Entertainment segment. Our range are down at the Entertainment.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

You say, "Wait a minute, what were they last year?" Last year, we were down 50%. So a lot of this increased profit is coming from new efficiencies, which we discovered, new automation, centralization of services, you name it. There've been a lot of savings both in personnel and in methodology.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, I guess some of you just need to scale, I think, to it because at the end of the day, the TV station revenues are much smaller than the Network   revenues. So as you put it all together, when you combine Sports and the Network, and Entertainment and the Network, that pool of revenues is a much bigger pool than Television stations, which operate with a much higher margin. componenttext: No. I don't think we did at all, and we're far from sure that we're the only club involved. But we were shocked. componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. And welcome to the News Corp. Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn the conference over to Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, News Corp., Reed Nolte. Please go ahead.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter fiscal 2010 earnings conference call. On the call today are Rupert Murdoch, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dave
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter fiscal 2010 earnings conference call. On the call today are Rupert Murdoch, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dave DeVoe, our Chief Financial Officer. Dave will give a detailed presentation of the quarter results, followed by Rupert who will give his own perspective and color on the quarter. We'll then take your question, first from the financial community and then from the press.
This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to News Corporation's business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. News Corporation's Form 10-Q for the three months ended December 31, 2009, identifies the risks and opportunities that could cause actual results to differ. And these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filing. Additionally, this call includes certain non-GAAP financial measure. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found on our earnings release in our 10-Q filing. And with that, I'll turn it over to Dave.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Reed, thank you and good afternoon, everybody. As you all seen in today's earnings release, we're very pleased with the financial results of the third quarter of fiscal 2010. Revenues grew 19% over the third quarter a year ago, with increases in all of ou
componenttext:
Reed, thank you and good afternoon, everybody. As you all seen in today's earnings release, we're very pleased with the financial results of the third quarter of fiscal 2010. Revenues grew 19% over the third quarter a year ago, with increases in all of our major segments led by double-digit increases in our Filmed Entertainment, Cable Networks, Newspapers and Book Publishing segments. 
Fueled by this top line growth and benefiting from our cost reduction efforts, segment operating income exceeded $1.25 billion, an improvement of 55% from a year ago. This growth rises to 67% after considering the absence of NDS results from this year. 
Net income in the quarter was $839 million with earnings per share of $0.32. This compares to last year's third quarter's net income of $2.7 billion or $1.04 a share. And as a reminder, the year ago quarter included a one-time items of $1.1 billion in after-tax income or $0.43 a share. This largely reflects the gain on the NDS transaction, as well a one-time non-cash tax benefit of $1.2 billion or $0.46 a share.
Included in this year's results are one-time items netting to after-tax income of $79 million or $0.03 a share and this is primarily related to News Corporation's share of BSkyB's gain on their partial sale of ITV, and a tax benefit associated with an asset sale. 
And looking at our businesses this quarter, clearly the standout performances were from our Cable and Filmed segments, which together delivered nearly $1.1 billion of the company's operating profit.
At our Cable Networks, we continue to deliver solid growth with operating income contributions up 38%, on 16% higher revenues. Overall affiliate fees increased 16% from growth across all the channels and advertising revenues were up 19%, reflecting the strength of FOX News in our International Cable businesses. 
Our Cable Networks now account for nearly 50% of our operating income. And we expect this percentage to continue to increase. The primary drivers behind the year-over-year increases were from the FOX News Channel, which achieved its highest ever quarterly profit due to strong affiliate fees and advertising increases.  The March quarter was the channel's highest rated quarter in the network history in terms of total viewers. 
At this point, we have renegotiated all the original carriage deals with major cable and satellite distributors that were made at the launch. And renewals will begin again at the end of this calendar year.
Our Regional Sports Networks has also generated higher profit contributions driven by double-digit affiliate revenue increases. The advertising revenues were up only slightly in the March quarter which was adversely impacted by the NHL Olympic break. More recent trends suggest the advertising and local sports are starting to follow the upswing we are seeing at our local broadcast Television stations. 
The Fox International Channel has also reported a 48% profit increase on strong advertising and affiliate revenue growth, particularly in Europe and Asia. 
And finally, at our STAR businesses. In India and Greater China are showing renewed strength with higher profit contribution supported by advertising increases. STAR Plus and India has regained its leadership position in ratings and the strength of our Bengali regional channels and South Indian channels continue to drive higher revenues and profits.
At our Filmed segment, third quarter operating income was a record $497 million, up $215 million or 76% over last year's result. This strong performance was very much driven by the phenomenal success of Avatar, with over $2.7 billion in worldwide box office receipts. The quarter also benefited from the theatrical success of Alvin and the Chipmunks 2, as well as continued strong home entertainment performances from Ice Age, X-Men, and Night at the Museum 2.
Turning to our Pay Television business. SKY Italia, SKY generated segment operating income of $35 million as compared to $63 million in the third quarter a year ago, reflecting the continued challenging business and economic environment in Italy. While SKY Italia's financial results are clearly not as strong as we like to report, we continue to remain very confident in the local growth of this profitable business in this under-penetrated market. 
Total revenues at SKY declined 3% in local currency terms as compared to the prior quarter, largely reflecting a fewer average subscribers and flat ARPU in the quarter compared to a year ago. Overall cost were flat as higher sports-related costs were offset by savings and other programming and subscriber acquisition costs. SKY Italia subscriber base declined by 39,000 compared with the previous quarter end as total quarterly gross additions of 118,000 were more than offset by churn.
SKY's total subscriber count at end of quarter was 4.7 million subscribers. At the end of the March quarter, over 2.4 million subscribers representing approximately 54% of the subscriber base were taking an HD or PVR premium service compared with approximately 26% of the base a year ago. 
As a result of the growth in these premium services, we've begun to see some improvement in the overall churn rate. And currently, the annual churn rate is expected to be approximately 13%, which is consistent with the prior year. We expect the upcoming World Cup broadcast in June, as well as increased adoption of premium services will help stabilize churn and return SKY to growing subscribers.
Our Television segment generated operating income in the quarter of $40 million as compared to $9 million reported in the third quarter a year ago. This $30 million improvement was driven by strong revenue growth at our Television Stations, partially offset by increased losses at the broadcast network from lower ratings. 
Station revenues were up 18% on the quarter compared to a year ago, reflecting improved local advertising trends, particularly in the automotive and telecommunications sectors. As a result of the cost containment initiatives at the stations, their entire revenue increased was converted to increased earnings.
Shifting to Newspapers and Information Services. Operating income in this sector -- this year's quarter was $131 million. This is up nearly fivefold from $29 million reported a year ago. The substantial improvement is largely driven by higher advertising across all our markets and lower operating expenses throughout all our Newspaper businesses. 
Ad growth to The Wall Street Journal was approximately 25%, while our U.K. titles in local currency revenues increased by nearly 10%. Our Newspaper results also benefited from favorable foreign exchange impact of nearly $30 million related to the strengthening of the Australian dollar against the U.S. dollar. 
And at our Other segment, we reported a third-quarter operating loss of $150 million as compared to a loss of $88 million a year ago. The $62 million increase primarily reflects the absence of NDS' operating profits this year due to its partial sale in early February of 2009. The third quarter of year ago including $60 million in NDS operating income. Additionally, the Digital Media group reported higher losses principally from lower search and advertising revenues, offset in part by cost reductions from our recent restructuring.
And before I address our guidance, I just like to make a couple of comments related to our balance sheet. Our gross debt balance at the end of March quarter was $13.5 billion, a reduction of nearly $1.8 billion from the prior quarter. Our cash balance at quarter end was nearly $8.2 billion, an increase of over $900 million. These balance is taken into account the receipt of $900 million of the Dow Jones Index-related transactions, the redemption of substantially all-of-the-box exchangeable securities at $1.6 billion outflow, the maturity and repayment of $150 million senior note and approximately $2.1 billion in cash flow from operations less CapEx in the quarter. 
Note that this very high cash flow from operations includes the receipt of the majority of Avatar's box office revenues. A sizable portion of which will be paid to third-party participants on the film in this current June quarter.
Our strong free cash flow generation in conjunction with asset sales has led to the buildup of significant cash balances. We are well aware of the resulting inefficient capital structure and are evaluating options for the best use of our surplus cash. This is an important area of focus for us and our Board of Directors as we proceed to our fiscal year 2011 budget process, which is currently underway. We intend to revise guidance on this issue by our next earnings call.
And finally, let me address our earnings guidance for the remainder of fiscal 2010. As a reminder, we measure this guidance, excluding from the fiscal 2009 segment operating income results, the $121 million in operating profit from NDF [ph](18:16) which is no longer consolidated in our results. So as we look at measuring growth in fiscal 2010, we are comparing it to a base of $3.44 billion in segment operating profit for fiscal 2009. 
In early February, we gave guidance anticipating our operating income growth rate for fiscal 2010 to be in the low 20% range, above the $3.44 billion fiscal 2009 adjusted result. Although we have performed better than anticipated in several of our businesses resulting in the 42% growth rate we just reported for the first nine months, we are currently forecasting our fourth quarter results to be down from a year ago. 
The primary reason for this is that despite the solid home entertainment performance forecasted for Avatar, we are expecting the Filmed segment to be down approximately $100 million from last year, principally due to year-over-year timing of releases. 
Last year's very strong results included a significant number of home entertainment in free and paid TV releases. And also this year, we are expecting slightly higher releasing cost for our June releases. In addition, we are projecting lower results at FBC due to higher programming costs, lower network revenues and higher marketing in support of our summer schedule. 
As a result, taking all these items into account and excluding the effect to the prior year's Valassis litigation settlement, we are increasing our operating income guidance to a growth rate of in the high 20% range above the fiscal 2009 adjusted results. 
I think it's important to underscore that this upcoming fourth quarter comparison is not at all indicative of the overall growth momentum of our businesses. While it's premature to get into a discussion around the guidance for our net fiscal year, we feel very good about the continued growth momentum for the company as we look to 2011. With that, I'd now like to turn the call over to Rupert for his comments.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. David just reviewed with you, we had really exceptional results in this last quarter, pretty much across the board. We do feel good, not just about this quarter but about the rest of the year and bey
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. David just reviewed with you, we had really exceptional results in this last quarter, pretty much across the board. We do feel good, not just about this quarter but about the rest of the year and beyond. And I think it's for five reasons. 
First is the primacy of our content. On this call, last quarter, I spent a lot of time discussing the value of content and the crucial role of content place in the future of our company. Our results this past quarter continue to bear that out. Content is driving our outstanding performance, from the history-making film Avatar to the unstoppable FOX News Channel, to our popular regional sports channels, to new hit chart like Glee and Modern Family. The growth at our flagship newspapers and international channels. 
Fortune favors the bold. From the every rated media [ph](21:31) our approach to opponent is setting new standards to success and redefining the industry. In film, Avatar is not only number one, it is redefined 3D. In Television, to the number one entertainment network, we have the number one news network. Something we would tell was impossible. And with the line used to be division, is only 17% of our total business. We have the number one national paper on all three continents. 
The second reason I'm confident about our future, is that we continue to extend our core businesses in innovative ways. New technologies like 3D and mobile platforms are opening up new avenues for real revenue growth. Just last month, Apple introduced its iPad, which I believe will lead a revolution in media consumption and create added value for both our news and entertainment content.
And I said last time, these new digital devices are entirely dependent on the flow of high-quality content, the business we are in. We're uniquely poised to capitalize on this proliferation, which is providing another revenue stream for publishers and studios. The news, for example, we live in a world with a consumption adjournment has never been greater. By taking advantage of innovations such as the iPad, we are now delivering first-rate journalism in ways that cater to a new generation of consumers. A generation that relies on digital devices for professional and personal use. 
And just the first month alone, we have more than 64,000 active users for the WSJ iPad app, and I'm not kindle. We keep a 100% of the subscriber revenue with the iPad. Today, we are in final discussions with a number of publishers, device makers and technology companies, and we will assume develop an innovative subscription model that will deliver digital content to consumers, wherever and whenever they want it. 
In a couple of weeks ago, for example, FOX led a consortium of American Broadcast Groups, and announced a joint venture, one that will develop a new national mobile content service using broadcast spectrum we already owned. It could prove a financial boom to companies like us, with the wealth of valuable local and national news content.
The third reason I'm bullish on News Corporations future is that our core businesses are strongly positioned to grow for the foreseeable future. In Broadcasting, we're now on track to build a jewel revenue on stream that enables FOX to achieve real value. One that equals the strength and importance to viewers. And we will continue to innovate hard [ph](24:39) with all our distribution partners to ensure we remain on this track. Retransmission is a real breakthrough. 
In Cable, our channels are young. They have great momentum and plenty of room for growth, both in the United States and internationally. This business accounts now for about half of our total company's earnings. 
In the U.S., we are leading a competition, we call it quality brands, like FOX News, FOX Business, FX and NatGeo. And internationally, we have put a position of true leadership with FOX International Channels, one that will only continue to strengthen as multichannel subscription TV around the world catches up with the U.S. 
 
Finally, we continue to sharpen our focus by divesting non-core businesses, like bTV, say, Balkan's TV and the Dow Jones index business, while further investing in businesses in regions with high growth potential, such as Germany and the Middle East. 
Let me close by saying that in the ad markets, we are currently seeing strong across-the-board growth, particularly in the U.S. and Britain. That bodes well for many of our core businesses. We're optimistic about the trends we're seeing. We're even more optimistic about the clear momentum in our businesses, which will indicate our strategy and build greater shareholder value. So thank you very much, and we'll be happy to answer your questions.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Doug Mitchelson with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Doug Mitchelson with Deutsche Bank.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question for Rupert and Chase. Including fiscal year '10, seven in the last 10 years, News Corp. put up double-digit EBIT growth, and two of those three years that you did not were recession years and the other was 8% growth. So I think, as we lo
componenttext: I have a question for Rupert and Chase. Including fiscal year '10, seven in the last 10 years, News Corp. put up double-digit EBIT growth, and two of those three years that you did not were recession years and the other was 8% growth. So I think, as we look forward to 2011, there's a lot of concern among investors, you're not going to be able to keep up the same strong growth pace that you delivered last decade, partly due to tough film comps. So my question is, do you believe strong growth will continue in fiscal '11? And if so, what gives you that confidence?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, but not 67%. And how strong? Will they be in single digits or double digits? I don't know. A lot of it's in timing on the films. We have, as a matter of fact, a great slate of films coming up, but we don't have an Avatar in there. But tha
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, but not 67%. And how strong? Will they be in single digits or double digits? I don't know. A lot of it's in timing on the films. We have, as a matter of fact, a great slate of films coming up, but we don't have an Avatar in there. But that will be more than compensated for by the outstanding growth, which is guaranteed in our cable channels. So if this present growth in advertising, that's very evident at the moment, continues, I think we can be very confident.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I guess to add to that, probably in the Film segment, we delivered tough comparison because of Avatar [indiscernible] (28:04) really across the rest of the business. And certainly, the Cable business continues to have great momentum. You see
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I guess to add to that, probably in the Film segment, we delivered tough comparison because of Avatar [indiscernible] (28:04) really across the rest of the business. And certainly, the Cable business continues to have great momentum. You see it in the numbers, and there's really no reason we don't continue to build on that. If anything, you've got sort of an ad market that is even picking up. And so, when you look at some of the sports businesses, it's probably been up a little slower than others, in terms of the ad markets shaking up and they're now seeing a pickup. I think the Station business, actually, currently has some favorable comparisons. When you look at the first half of last year, some benefits there. So I think we look at those, and since we got an ad market out there, they're really, right now, on almost every level. It looks great and it continues to be a strong scatter market, on both the Cable and Broadcast side. You continue to have sort of, really, competition you haven't seen for a while in key sectors of the ad market, whether it's auto, it's for retail, or telecom, consumer electronics. Again, I think we get some benefits from the Newspapers side, with comparisons against a year ago and sort of expect to continue to see the momentum there. So it is a set of businesses that I think we feel pretty good about. And as you look at something like the Broadcast business, retrans [retransmission] is clearly just going to continue to build, as more players come up and we move through the next few years. So that will clearly be helping both the stations and the network, so -- and then, we think we got the momentum to the majority of our businesses.

componenttext: Dave, I just wondered if you could give us some more details on what capital management options are being considered?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Rupert, do you want me to do that?
componenttext: Rupert, do you want me to do that?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I can answer that if you like. And just to say that we're well aware that our balance sheet, as Dave said, has limitations at the moment, given the amount of cash we have. We're looking at all our options to make best use of this cash and expect to take a
componenttext: I can answer that if you like. And just to say that we're well aware that our balance sheet, as Dave said, has limitations at the moment, given the amount of cash we have. We're looking at all our options to make best use of this cash and expect to take actions within the next three months. Options available to us include: increased dividends, stock buybacks, debt repayments and investing in our businesses, and always opportunistic to make accretive investments that generate a good return for shareholders. I think we have not done this in the last year because we've been nervously on top of the world economy. Wherever we looked, it looked pretty fragile, and now there is a growing air of confidence. So we'll see. But if the opportunities that arise in the way that we expect to in the next few months, we will do something else.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: That question comes from the line of David Bank with RBC Capital.
componenttext: That question comes from the line of David Bank with RBC Capital.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color, in terms of the near-term momentum, particularly in local TV and newspaper, characterized stations in local TV and newspaper. And then more specifically, in the press release, you talked about aut
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color, in terms of the near-term momentum, particularly in local TV and newspaper, characterized stations in local TV and newspaper. And then more specifically, in the press release, you talked about auto and telecom being the standout categories. Auto has been a big driver. Are you starting to see a kind of a broader recovery in more categories' difference between first calendar quarter and second calendar quarter?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, first, I think, in terms of momentum, I think the Station business for the quarter we're in is sort of in the mid-20s. I think, even plus that, as we go through the quarter. So it's certainly, probably stronger than it's been, if anything. An
componenttext: Yes. I mean, first, I think, in terms of momentum, I think the Station business for the quarter we're in is sort of in the mid-20s. I think, even plus that, as we go through the quarter. So it's certainly, probably stronger than it's been, if anything. And it really is a broad based -- I mean, at this point, really pretty much than in most categories. So it's not just auto and telecom. I mean, again, if you look at the retail sector, you'll look at stuff -- even the financial sector, which people have talked about, and you've got nice competition in the insurance space. So it's pretty broad. And again, provides pretty healthy dynamics. Now pharmaceutical sector does not want that one where that begin to. And maybe not all of them, but I'd say it's a broad healthy market with anything, sort of, I think, people feeling there's more competition for market share and awareness that if you want to try and be in the game and you want to build the brand, you've got market it. And I think television, in particular, has once again sort of proven the test of time that, as much as we're ready, we sort of want some of these other new mediums to emerge. The power of television advertising is second to none. But it really is -- it is certainly not driven by a couple of factors. It's a broad, healthy market right now.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll just add to that. I think we're seeing pretty optimistic and expanded advertising budgets from the big advertisers. When that money will drop, whether it will be in our first fiscal quarter or the second one, I would be inclined to bet that it'd be m
componenttext: I'll just add to that. I think we're seeing pretty optimistic and expanded advertising budgets from the big advertisers. When that money will drop, whether it will be in our first fiscal quarter or the second one, I would be inclined to bet that it'd be more in the second one, when they're launching all their new car models. But there's a lot of money out there on the boards, and our advertising people are really, really optimistic so I'd be [ph] upfront on the network. And although we get a higher cost per thousand, as pretty [ph] over the year, audiences shrink and ours were shrunk much less than anybody else's, that money is finding it's way across into the cable networks. And people now, more and more, they do their own networking, they've all got a DVR. And those shows any sort of a rating can attract that good advertising. So it feels good. That's all I'm saying.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Jessica Reif-Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that you mentioned that the FOX News affiliate agreements are coming up at the end of this calendar year. I was wondering -- you had very strong increases in the last go-round. I was wondering if you could kind of frame for us how you're thinking
componenttext: I think that you mentioned that the FOX News affiliate agreements are coming up at the end of this calendar year. I was wondering -- you had very strong increases in the last go-round. I was wondering if you could kind of frame for us how you're thinking about the next round of negotiations. And then separately, if there was any weak link and all in the quarter, it was SKY Italia. I'm just wondering if you could talk about plans over the next few years to drive penetration in that market?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, I mean, first, in FOX News, I think what we said is they start to come up. They obviously like come up over time, so it's not one fell swoop. So they began, but it'll be a number of years, over which agreements come up. And I'm not going to
componenttext: Yes. I think, I mean, first, in FOX News, I think what we said is they start to come up. They obviously like come up over time, so it's not one fell swoop. So they began, but it'll be a number of years, over which agreements come up. And I'm not going to get too specific and sort of can't make [ph] (35:34) -- I think you should ask negotiations in private, not in public. So I'm probably not going to sort of put out there any specifics on what our expectations, other than look at, I think, the FOX News Network and the power and importance of it is certainly, maybe with the FBN, second to none. I mean, I think it is a channel that has built an enormous following and enormous audience. It's  tremendously important to some kind of a major segment [ph] (35:59) of the country out there, and heading into a complicated political arena that probably gets more complicated as you go between now and 2012. I think the importance of that channel and the value of that channel probably has never been higher. And what we're going to do is get fair value for that channel. So certainly, they will pursue that appropriately and practically.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of SKY Italia, it probably is somewhat what we talked about a quarter ago. I mean, SKY Italia, since the -- and beginning middle of last year, it's clearly gone through a tough stretch. The economy actually continues to be tough. But I think more
componenttext: In terms of SKY Italia, it probably is somewhat what we talked about a quarter ago. I mean, SKY Italia, since the -- and beginning middle of last year, it's clearly gone through a tough stretch. The economy actually continues to be tough. But I think more so, it had a number of factors. Probably, I think, the biggest one being the tax that was thrown at it and we've largely digested that, and now, it's sort of renewals in a more ordinary rate. We had to restructure sales because media sets pulled the ability to advertise on TV. We got a competitor we didn't have, which is okay, but it's better we had some short-term advantages, in terms of cost and programming like sports. So we digested those. Maybe we digested those reasonably well. We've invested in building a foundation. I guess, really, I'd say, initially, foundation for long-term growth. And we really do think this is a great long-term play and that's about making sure we're the quality player there, clearly investing in HD and DVR technology. I think -- and that's still happening. We're going to ramp up to that 30 HD channels in the next month or so. We were only about 10 in the beginning of this year. I think we've got about a third of our customers now have HD. So that's come out. I think, actually over half our customers have HD and DVR, on second thought. So the quality installation in the home is growing. And again, that's not going to pay off in a quarter. That's going to pay off over time, as you build behind that. We overhauled our packages to be more aggressive in the market. So I actually think we've done a good job building a foundation. And I think our priority, if you look in the short term, the next year, really should be on re-energizing momentum, from a subscriber perspective, into the business. And I think that's where -- and that's what I guess I would say, it's really where our focus should be. I think, obviously, that's both churn in sales, I think as Dave touched on. We've already started to make some headline in churn. And as we guide to the tax and the like, I think we'll make further headlines. I think on the sales side we've got some momentum to that. We've got some events that'll help us. I think the HD and DVR, again, had incremental traction. I think our sales organization is sort of reorganized up big years to selling without reliance on TV advertising that they've had in the past, and are getting much better at doing that. So I think we feel very good about our competitive position. Clearly, some of the regulatory issues that reside under our -- changed the end of next year. And we feel it. We think there'll be competition there, but we think we have a great proposition with the quality offerings that really doesn't have a peer on that market that really, still is in the early stages of its growth. Again, I think our short-term focus should be on driving that business forward, in terms of subscribers. And I think profitability will follow behind it, in volume [ph] (39:26), and I still expect this to be a great business for us.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Adam Alexander with JBWere.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to touch on a couple of the associates, which look I think, big drivers of EPS growth in the next couple of years. First one, Sky D. Chase, could you just give us an update on your initial thoughts to that business now you've become the Chairm
componenttext: I just want to touch on a couple of the associates, which look I think, big drivers of EPS growth in the next couple of years. First one, Sky D. Chase, could you just give us an update on your initial thoughts to that business now you've become the Chairman there? And then on BSkyB, it delivered another great result last week. The business looks in fantastic shape. Do you think News Corp. would get greater recognition of the strength of that business if it was consolidated?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think in Sky Deutschland, I mean, I think they announced earnings next week. So I'd probably not going to get too far in front of their announcement. Sky Deutschland, they haven't been in as long as Italy. And probably, in some ways, some of the thi
componenttext: And I think in Sky Deutschland, I mean, I think they announced earnings next week. So I'd probably not going to get too far in front of their announcement. Sky Deutschland, they haven't been in as long as Italy. And probably, in some ways, some of the things you just said are kind of true there, though at an early stage. We've got some new management there, which I think we're very excited about, bringing some of the expertise from BSkyB to, and into Germany and Brian Sullivan. We've made some of the moves in HD and DVRs that were just right now, putting out the HD DVR box. We maybe just, more recently, overhaul the program packaging and the branding there. And it's a different market. Obviously, with cable and sort of the dual distribution to cable and up cable and satellite. And so it's not just a calling of the others, but -- and then we've taken a lot of steps, so as to put it on better footing, as clearly a work in progress. There's no two ways about that. Above all [ph] (41:02), Germany is a great market. I mean, I was just there for a meeting I've been to, and you can't help but be -- it's about the rest there [ph]  (41:10), you can't help but be impressed about Germany. And I think there is a great momentum to that. A great opportunity to really build a really unique, strong business. It'll take time. It is not a 12-month plan. This is a plan to build over time. I do believe that as we build on those strengths and really get traction in things like HD, and get the right technology, in terms of set top boxes and get an organization that continues to grow in expertise and strength, in terms of selling and servicing that business. We are, again, still building some of that foundation. But I think we've got it going in the right direction, but clearly, not minimizing. The work is in front of us, but I think, equally not minimizing, I think, the opportunity in front of us, with a country like Germany. At Sky -- I mean, Sky is a great business. And I admire them for the strength they've built. And we've been a happy shareholder for 15 years. We are controlling shareholder, and I think happy and comfortable with the shareholding we have.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And that question comes from the line of Jason Bazinet with Citi.
componenttext: And that question comes from the line of Jason Bazinet with Citi.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of folks on the buy set are looking at the acceleration of Netflix results with great interest. And I was just wondering, as you watch that business evolve, do you look at that as a good news story because it's an effective way to monetize s
componenttext: I think a lot of folks on the buy set are looking at the acceleration of Netflix results with great interest. And I was just wondering, as you watch that business evolve, do you look at that as a good news story because it's an effective way to monetize sort of the older content within your library? Or do you look at it potentially as an opportunity to monetize your library in a better way, maybe better than you are today? And how might the industry sort of change or evolve, do you think, over the next, call it, two to three years, if at all?

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably something we need to continue evaluate. So I wouldn't probably, at this point, come down clearly on either side. I think we look at it as important for us to continuing on. It's one of the greatest things of being content owners, it'
componenttext: I think it's probably something we need to continue evaluate. So I wouldn't probably, at this point, come down clearly on either side. I think we look at it as important for us to continuing on. It's one of the greatest things of being content owners, it's the ability to develop different windows and different ways to monetize our product and provide products to consumers in interesting ways, in interesting shapes and forms. I think there is a question whether the Netflix model is getting us fair value for our product, and I think that's a question we need to continue to evaluate and perhaps taken some steps, in terms of already moving windows, with some players on some of the newer releases. And like I think, as digital evolves, as VOD evolves, these windows are clearly continually evolving business. And we need to continue to study it and get smarter about it, and make sure we're getting the value we should be getting for our products and not having our product undervalued or devalued as it becomes available in the marketplace. So I think it's a focus, and something that I think you'll see continue to evolve as we go through the next few years.

headline: News Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
