componenttext: No. Jason, it's $0.01 a share on Easynet, and the currency in the quarter is really -- it's marginal.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that comes from Ben Swinburne, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And that comes from Ben Swinburne, Morgan Stanley.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chase, I wanted to go back to the network. You talked about retransmission revenue, which clearly News Corp. has led the charge on and gotten the math for. But I was wondering on the cost side, as you look at the network and particularly sports, how you'r
componenttext: Chase, I wanted to go back to the network. You talked about retransmission revenue, which clearly News Corp. has led the charge on and gotten the math for. But I was wondering on the cost side, as you look at the network and particularly sports, how you're thinking about this business over the long term. I think Fox, I believe probably spends more on sports programming than any other network. You've got, in addition to the NFL, baseball, NASCAR, is there something you think needs to change over the long term? Do you think the retrans revenue stream fixes the business given how much sports costs? Or you want to see that move more and more to your cable properties where you've built, obviously, a Regional Sports Network business that's very attractive?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I mean and I guess on the last point, I mean, I really think that about our Broadcast Network more and more should be thought of in the same way as Cable Network. And therefore, I don't -- and I know that you're differentiating one from the o
componenttext: Well, first, I mean and I guess on the last point, I mean, I really think that about our Broadcast Network more and more should be thought of in the same way as Cable Network. And therefore, I don't -- and I know that you're differentiating one from the other. They've got to become dual revenue businesses that receive revenues that are reflective of their strength, and that's what we're driving the Fox Network to be. It's a business that looks essentially much more like our Cable Networks. I guess in the sport line, sports programming is always a double-edged sword. It has great strength, great value. Look at the NFL right now. In a world of fragmentation, it continues to set records. As I said, we like another World Series game or two and that's the variation in it, but it's still great content in baseball. The programming has great appeal. Sports has a unique strength in the world of DVRs and all the like. There isn't anything like it. There isn't a second World Series or a second Super Bowl or a second NFC Championship Game. And it has a unique value in the marketplace. The issue with it is they come with big price tags. And it's been a great part of building Fox. We'd like it to continue to be a part of building Fox. But we've got to negotiate rates that enable us to believe it makes sense. I think our goal -- we think it has been important, it's been valuable to us. We'd like it to continue to be a part of our story, but we've got to make sure it's on terms that makes sense. Obviously, retransmission does help. I mean, I think it's -- if you've been an ad-supported only, an asset only business, I think probably over time you wouldn't find any of these sports on any of the networks on that business model. But I think as they build the business model, that enables them to compete in a more level playing field. It has profitable businesses with exciting long-term futures, and it enable to compete for rights. But as with any rights, you've got to be disciplined. And at some point, rights get too expensive, the rights we clearly like to have and I'd certainly put sports rights in that category.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow up to some of the earlier calls on digital distribution, TV Everywhere and authentication is starting to come to fruition a little bit in the market. But you've made some waves around Google TV. I think someone from Google was quoted
componenttext: And just as a follow up to some of the earlier calls on digital distribution, TV Everywhere and authentication is starting to come to fruition a little bit in the market. But you've made some waves around Google TV. I think someone from Google was quoted in the press as saying the broadcasters don't get it. And one question I'm wondering if you would address is are you thinking about different devices or different screens as a way to window this content, which is a little bit of a nuance versus how we typically think about windowing, which is just the calendar? In other words, would you make content available on a mobile platform or on a PC, but disable it on the television screen? How do you think about that piece of the story?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think in the house, the difference between screens, I mean, is going to continue to diminish their sort of PC and TV as you get more Internet-ready TVs and the like. I do think mobile is probably a more discrete platform that is obviously different beca
componenttext: I think in the house, the difference between screens, I mean, is going to continue to diminish their sort of PC and TV as you get more Internet-ready TVs and the like. I do think mobile is probably a more discrete platform that is obviously different because it has the really get it anywhere. I do think the iPad or the tablet devices are really going to redefine that whole mobile experience. So it's very early stages, and I think what will be the true -- I think the apps will grow fast now to the next couple of years. You'll really start to have a big enough universe out there to meaningfully determine how do you develop -- how do we build on that opportunity. It is a real opportunity for us. Then I'm not sure if you went into the home system with the screens, the way longer term -- I think in the short term, it can exist. But I do think those screens are going to blend. And I think it does come back to figuring out probably more what is the business models for our content and what are the right terms, and I think we need to -- you're right, our content is tremendously valuable. We need to manage it. We need to make sure as we make it available, we're making it available on the right terms and much as like the movie business has done historically, creating a series of windows that went from theatrical to video to pay to free. Now it's talking about a VOD window that may be ahead of the DVD window that you continue to figure how do you create the right windows on the right business terms. I do think one of the things that I would get public about and people talk about, broadcasters versus cable, and I think that distinction is sort of ill-founded. I mean, in essence, if you're going to create original programming on a cable channel, why is that sort of one set of rules versus great original programming on a network. I mean, it's great original programming. You ought to manage it accordingly, figure out how do you exploit that programming. I think it's a good thing for us to enable our customers to access that programming in new and exciting and interesting ways. I think that it's a great opportunity for us to do that. But we need to do it in ways that have us fairly compensated for the value of our content. Our content is incredibly valuable. You can't just throw it out there to everybody. We got to make sure that we're putting it out there on terms that get us fairly compensated for the content we create.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Comes from Tom Eagan, Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Comes from Tom Eagan, Collins Stewart.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Just on Home Entertainment revenue, Chase. I think at Time Warner they said that year-to-date, their home entertainment revenue was up about 8%. What was your date so far at News Corp.?

componenttextpreview: I think it's actually up about 10%. And the Home Entertainment business, because sort of a lot of people are sort of going down, it's actually stabilized for us and actually even some segments that were going down, we're actually seeing some nice light in
componenttext: I think it's actually up about 10%. And the Home Entertainment business, because sort of a lot of people are sort of going down, it's actually stabilized for us and actually even some segments that were going down, we're actually seeing some nice light in right now.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: And then separately on TV syndication, you mentioned Modern Family. Remind us what other titles should we be thinking about for the balance of fiscal '11.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think Dave cited a couple, so I don't -- How I Met Your Mother is one that came in. There are couple of cable properties I think that -- there's American Dad, and I'd say, I don't remember which one of the cable originals, but one of the cable f
componenttext: I mean, I think Dave cited a couple, so I don't -- How I Met Your Mother is one that came in. There are couple of cable properties I think that -- there's American Dad, and I'd say, I don't remember which one of the cable originals, but one of the cable franchises as well.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the pricing of that, are you seeing it up from what it was a year ago?
componenttext: And on the pricing of that, are you seeing it up from what it was a year ago?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's tough -- shows are different shows. I mean, I can't -- I mean, it's been apples and oranges to sort of compare one to the other. I mean, certainly, I think the cable market as a volume market continues to be a very strong market. I think you've seen
componenttext: It's tough -- shows are different shows. I mean, I can't -- I mean, it's been apples and oranges to sort of compare one to the other. I mean, certainly, I think the cable market as a volume market continues to be a very strong market. I think you've seen industry segments that sort of the prices of things like half hours really move to -- and we obviously we're beneficiary in our Modern Family, moved to whole new levels just in the last year plus. So the market is there. And I think the Broadcast business certainly has come out of the hole it was in a couple of years ago. We've got to strike a stronger ad market there. And I think that market certainly seems to have stabilized. But it's tough to make those year-on-year comparisons because it's going to be title-driven.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That comes from Spencer Wang, Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: That comes from Spencer Wang, Crdit Suisse.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just two quick questions, the first for Chase. Recognizing that you guys are still involved in the BSkyB transaction, but was wondering if you could speak to News Corp.'s appetite for acquisitions at this stage? There's been some chatter about perhaps som
componenttext: Just two quick questions, the first for Chase. Recognizing that you guys are still involved in the BSkyB transaction, but was wondering if you could speak to News Corp.'s appetite for acquisitions at this stage? There's been some chatter about perhaps some interest in Yahoo! with the help of outside financing, for example. And then secondly, perhaps for Dave, I know you said that the TV stations are running up about 20% in ad revenues quarter to date. Was wondering if you could give us a sense of how the pacings are looking post the elections for the rest of the quarter.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, some things like Yahoo! are the press needing to have things to write about. But I think we are now certainly do not need to make any acquisitions. I think we've got a great portfolio of businesses that we can grow aggressively that have a
componenttext: Well, I guess, some things like Yahoo! are the press needing to have things to write about. But I think we are now certainly do not need to make any acquisitions. I think we've got a great portfolio of businesses that we can grow aggressively that have a good diversification amongst them. Though I think what we want to be is make sure we're smart about things and look at things that are out there. And if there's something there, then we should consider it. But we're going to do so in a very disciplined way. I mean, we said we looked at a cable channel, we looked at a travel channel a year ago. We kicked the tires on something overseas recently. And ultimately, they were people who were looking for values that didn't make sense to us. And our general preference is to build businesses not buy businesses. It's the way we built the great businesses in News Corp. It's what our focus will continue to remain. But if we see something that we think we could acquire at a very attractive price that fits, I think we want to take a look at it. And we're going to do so in a very disciplined way. We're certainly not out shopping for anything. And again, I think our priority and focus and our preference is to build businesses. And I think we've got real opportunities to do that.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the pacing, we're staying pretty strong in the second quarter. I think we're around 11% x political. So business is very, very healthy.
componenttext: On the pacing, we're staying pretty strong in the second quarter. I think we're around 11% x political. So business is very, very healthy.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chase, more on Cable Networks, I guess Dave and Chase. Dave, I just want to make sure there's no unusual items that's driving the growth in Cable Networks like acquisitions? And then Chase, you talked in this call about building rather buying. You talked
componenttext: Chase, more on Cable Networks, I guess Dave and Chase. Dave, I just want to make sure there's no unusual items that's driving the growth in Cable Networks like acquisitions? And then Chase, you talked in this call about building rather buying. You talked about the young channels that are driving such strong growth there. Today's young channels were yesterday's new launches. I'm curious, when you look at the strategic outlook for Cable Networks, is there a focus on or a need to continue to stoke the fire with more new cable network launches? Or is this stable of channels that we should be thinking about for the foreseeable future?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think the opportunities to build new channels is probably pretty few and far between. They've got a lot of them out there. I won't say there won't be one. But I think right now, you've got a pretty big group of channels. But we've got a lot of growt
componenttext: No, I think the opportunities to build new channels is probably pretty few and far between. They've got a lot of them out there. I won't say there won't be one. But I think right now, you've got a pretty big group of channels. But we've got a lot of growth. And we've got channels that -- FX and that of Nat Geo which we're still adding subscribers in a significant way that are -- that we have room to continue to grow even with our big channels. So it's not just the little channels where we can add to. And obviously overseas is a whole different case. I mean, overseas clearly is a market. There are business that are in much earlier stage. So the U.S. business, I think the places you'd add a channel would be fewer and farer between. I think internationally, it's a different case. I think domestically, the opportunities are really to take channels and take them to whole new levels. And again, I think -- I'll use examples that I used before -- make Nat Geo, Discovery or make FX, USA. And that opportunity would be those to be increasing our profit and cash flow by multiples not percentages.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's just driving the business. You're getting great franchise on cable channels with great revenue growth driving great margins.
componenttext: And that's just driving the business. You're getting great franchise on cable channels with great revenue growth driving great margins.

componenttext: Our domestic channels internationally?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Yes. Have you taken your domestic channels through your pay TV platforms internationally as much as you think you should?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've taken them very broadly. I mean, I guess our platforms, which, I guess, to be more specifically, the European platforms or India, we've certainly done some. But the international channels are really, with territories across the world, we certainly h
componenttext: We've taken them very broadly. I mean, I guess our platforms, which, I guess, to be more specifically, the European platforms or India, we've certainly done some. But the international channels are really, with territories across the world, we certainly have done it. I mean, in things like Nat Geo, some are more exportable than others. I mean, like Nat Geo, certainly, our content in entertainment, we have reviews to drive entertainment channels. Sports is probably a place that's a bit more local in its content. News, again, what we do some, it's probably a bit more local. But certainly, a big part of the international story is to take advantage of the economies and the efficiencies of using product that travels around the world. We've got a lot of product that travels around the world: movies, TVs, documentaries and the like. Some of it has been more local, but we've got an awful lot that travels around the world and that is what we look to take advantage of. And I guess in the cable channels, the growth, the other dimension of growth as we go forward is really the digital arena, how do you take this product and do people down the road want to get FOX News on an iPad so they can watch it when their not home, and how do you take forward and develop opportunities like that. And I think there an array of ways that we could continue to build and add to in ways that are exciting for customers and attractive for us. And let's build these franchises, build the content we launch in these franchises, original products. I mean, I think FX has done as good a job as anybody in the business in terms of launching great, unique original programming. How do we exploit it, how do we develop digital platforms with digital experiences for it that are compatible with FX. I mean, I think we have to make sure we do it in a way that is compatible with our core distributors and that makes sense and is additive to our business. But I think those opportunities are all there for us.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about wanting Broadcast to look more like Cable. Beyond growing the dual revenue stream, are there any ways that Broadcast can look Cable? And then I have a second question. How far off do you see a premium video window?
componenttext: You talked about wanting Broadcast to look more like Cable. Beyond growing the dual revenue stream, are there any ways that Broadcast can look Cable? And then I have a second question. How far off do you see a premium video window?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard. That's what I'm really talking about at dual revenue stream business. So it is really, and there are other nuances you can debate sort of about the Broadcast business. You create 25 pilots to find five shows. The cable business is more selectiv
componenttext: It's hard. That's what I'm really talking about at dual revenue stream business. So it is really, and there are other nuances you can debate sort of about the Broadcast business. You create 25 pilots to find five shows. The cable business is more selective about making commitments to something for 13 episodes and putting it on. So I think there are other aspects of -- but those businesses can learn from each other. But at its core, what you're really saying is you got a cable business that is a dual revenue business that is a very healthy strong business. You've got a broadcast business trying to compete with one arm behind its back without a dual revenue stream. And it needs to have a dual revenue to the strongest programming and have audiences that are multiples of any cable channel out there, and it ought to be fairly valued. And we've approached this realistically with a spirit of fairness. I mean, we could be asking if you're looking at it on competitive basis, we should be looking for a lot more than we are. And I think we've tried to be constructive about it.

componenttextpreview: Right now, we have a 28-day window. I think that's been a good thing for us. We haven't been there that long. I think we probably want to -- I do think it's something we'll continue to evaluate. So I think directionally, that's been a good thing. I think
componenttext: Right now, we have a 28-day window. I think that's been a good thing for us. We haven't been there that long. I think we probably want to -- I do think it's something we'll continue to evaluate. So I think directionally, that's been a good thing. I think we got to get a better handle and a bit more data around it to determine where and what is the right sequencing. I think as VOD continues to grow, you are going to continue to have change in the windowing strategy between DVDs and electronic and when people talk about premiums and the like that these things will continue to evolve. But again, what I'd say today is we feel the windowing we've done has been good for us, and we'll evaluate where we go from here as we go forward.

componenttextpreview: Look, our focus on three big businesses, two that are really in early growth -- I mean, one is very early growth stage in Germany. Italy, there was a lot of growth left ahead of it. And I think our focus is to build those businesses. We've got the channel
componenttext: Look, our focus on three big businesses, two that are really in early growth -- I mean, one is very early growth stage in Germany. Italy, there was a lot of growth left ahead of it. And I think our focus is to build those businesses. We've got the channel business across Europe, which has continued to grow. And I think there's some markets that I think are opportunities for us today to expand our channels. So again, back on sort of the build versus buy theme, I think our focus today is really to build the platforms in Italy and Germany, to build the channels we have across Europe. And I think we'll be opportunistic and see what's there. If there's something that makes sense, I think we'd look at it. But our honest focus is -- we're not out on a hunting or a shopping spree. I think our focus is on building those businesses.

componenttext: We know a lot about TV production. I guess I'd rather be building them than buying. I guess if there was something uniquely interesting, we'd look at it. And that will continue to be our focus, to build on those opportunities. We produce programming in a lot of countries today. We produce programming in Italy. We produce programming in India. We produce programming in places around the world. And we certainly have a lot of TV production going on, most of it in the U.S. But in an array of countries around the world. And again, our focus is going to continue to build those things.

componenttextpreview: I mean, in terms of the digital product in Europe, I mean, in the U.K., we feel very good about it. And realistically, it's very early. Digital as a whole, some of these platforms like tablets are just emerging. This is not something that is sort of a one
componenttext: I mean, in terms of the digital product in Europe, I mean, in the U.K., we feel very good about it. And realistically, it's very early. Digital as a whole, some of these platforms like tablets are just emerging. This is not something that is sort of a one or two quarter game. I mean, this is something that's going to continue to build over years. And I think we feel this is a great start, a great foundation. And we really look forward to continuing to build on this. And the whole digital arena is continuing to evolve and build. And we've got a lot to learn on the broader topic. I think we are looking at an array of digital opportunities. When we get to a place, if there's something we're going to do, we'll announce it.

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the News Corp. First Quarter 2011 Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the conference over to Reed Nolte, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations, News Corp. Please go ahead.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone and welcome to our first quarter fiscal 2011 earnings conference call. On the call today are Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dave DeVoe, our Chief Financial Officer. Rupert Murdoch wil
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone and welcome to our first quarter fiscal 2011 earnings conference call. On the call today are Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Dave DeVoe, our Chief Financial Officer. Rupert Murdoch will not be joining us today as he's been traveling overseas. First, we will give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, then we'll be happy to take your questions, first from the financial community and then from the press.
This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to News Corp.'s business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. News Corp.'s Form 10-Q for the three months ended September 30, 2010, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ, and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filing. Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing. And with that, I'll turn it over to Dave.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Reed, thank you, and good afternoon, everybody. As you all have seen in today's earnings release, we are very pleased with our start to fiscal 2011. Our first quarter segment operating income increased 8% over year-ago levels, led by the continuing strong
componenttext:
Reed, thank you, and good afternoon, everybody. As you all have seen in today's earnings release, we are very pleased with our start to fiscal 2011. Our first quarter segment operating income increased 8% over year-ago levels, led by the continuing strong growth at our Cable Programming, Television and Publishing segments that more than offset a difficult comparison at Filmed Entertainment. Net income in the quarter was $775 million, a 36% increase over the year-ago results. Earnings per share also increased 36% to $0.30 this year from $0.22 reported a year ago. This strong net earnings growth was driven by the higher segment operating income as well as improved earnings from affiliates, primarily at BSkyB led by a gain from the sale of their Easynet business.
Also included in this year's first quarter result is a tax benefit of approximately $90 million or $0.03 per share related to the resolution of various tax items. You will note that effective this quarter, we have combined the previously reported Book Publishing, Integrated Marketing Services and Newspaper and Information Service segments into a Publishing segment. This reporting change recognizes both the way we group these businesses and a smaller percentage of total earnings that these businesses now represent.
Now I'd like to provide some additional context on the performance of a few of our businesses. Let's start with the Cable Networks, which is our largest profit generator and accounted for over 57% of News Corp.'s total segment operating income this quarter. This segment continues to drive overall company results, with first quarter segment operating income contribution of $659 million. This is up 28% from last year and reflects double-digit growth at the majority of our channels. This growth continues to be top line-driven, with segment revenues up 17%. Advertising revenues at the Cable Networks increased 20% over year-ago levels and affiliate fees grew 14%, reflecting particular strength at the Regional Sports Networks, FOX News and our international channels. The strength of our Cable Network franchise continues to grow.
At FOX News in October, we drew more viewers than all of our news competitors combined. FX recently ranked as the number seven most popular cable channel among adults 18 to 49. Ratings at the Big Ten Networks have been setting records. And our fastest earnings grower, the international channels including the STAR, Fox and National Geographic-branded channels continue to expand and capitalize on particularly strong advertising markets, especially in India.
At our Film segment, first quarter operating income was $280 million, a good result, but as expected, well below the $391 million we reported a year ago. As we mentioned on the last quarter's earnings call, this anticipated decline reflects the very successful worldwide theatrical release of Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs in the prior year's result. Contributions from our television production businesses were up year-over-year, primarily reflecting the initial syndication release of two major shows, How I Met Your Mother and American Dad.
At our Television segment, operating income in the quarter of $105 million increased by $67 million. This improvement was driven by strong revenue growth at our television stations, partially offset by modestly higher losses at the broadcast network from program cancellation costs. Station advertising revenues were up 22% in the quarter compared to a year ago, reflecting improved local advertising trends particularly in the automotive, telecom and financial categories. Political revenues of $26 million were strong in the quarter and stayed healthy through yesterday's election.
Turning to SKY Italia. Revenues increased 2% in local currency terms as compared to the prior year's quarter, primarily driven by subscriber upgrade tickets and advertising for the World Cup coverage. SKY Italia generated segment operating income of $82 million, which is down from last year's $128 million result. This result primarily reflects rights cost associated with full coverage of the World Cup and increased subscriber acquisition costs related to the combination of both higher gross additions and a higher takeout of our full installation offer.
As mentioned on our last earnings conference call, SKY Italia's consumer offering was reorganized in July, more than doubling a subscriber's programming package choices. These new offerings also make the high-def [definition] PVR standard service to our subscribers. Results to date indicate that this increased consumer choice is stimulating subscriber growth, giving us increased confidence that we will hit our profit growth in subscriber targets this year.
In the quarter, higher gross additions totaling 193,000 and lower churn net to SKY Italia 58,000 additional subscribers. Now this compares to no subscriber growth in the first quarter a year ago. SKY ended the quarter with 4.8 million subscribers. The penetration of additional subscriber services such as high-def PVRs and second boxes, which helped reduced churn, doubled over the last year with approximately 70% of our subscriber base taking at least one of those services. Multi-ARPU in the quarter average EUR 43 as compared to EUR 42 last year.
In our newly defined Publishing segment, segment operating income of $178 million increased over 50% from the $118 million in last year's first quarter. This improvement is primarily due to increased advertising revenues in all three of our major market newspapers. Also, note that this improvement is despite the absence of Dow Jones Index business, which was sold last March. Year-ago results included about $14 million in segment operating profit from the Index business.
And then our Other segment, we reported the first quarter segment loss of $156 million. This is $30 million higher than a year ago. This increased loss primarily reflects $70 million in lower search and advertising revenues at MySpace versus a year ago. 
And finally, before I turn the call over to Chase, let me address our guidance for fiscal 2011. And as a reminder, just as we did at year end, we measured this guidance excluding from fiscal 2010 the $500 million litigation charge resulting in a base of $4.46 billion in segment operating income for comparative purposes.
In early August, we gave guidance and anticipated our segment operating income growth rates for fiscal 2011 to be in the low double-digit range above the $4.46 billion fiscal 2010 adjusted result. Since that time, the U.S. dollar has weakened more than we expected, thereby increasing our foreign source earnings. On the other hand, results at MySpace had been below planned. We've had to absorb the cost of cable carriage negotiation, and our new film releases were somewhat below our original expectations. 
As a result, taking all these items into account and based on all of the assumptions inherent in our projections, we are maintaining our operating segment income guidance for fiscal 2011 to a growth rate range in the low double digits above fiscal 2010 adjusted results. 
And with all that, I'd like to turn the call over to Chase.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. As Dave has summarized the financials pretty well for you, I thought I'd spend a few minutes adding a bit of color commentary to the results. While we feel good about our performance, we feel even better about the strides we're making to strengthe
componenttext:
Thanks. As Dave has summarized the financials pretty well for you, I thought I'd spend a few minutes adding a bit of color commentary to the results. While we feel good about our performance, we feel even better about the strides we're making to strengthen our business and position them for long-term growth. Clearly, as Dave said, our Network business, both Broadcast and Cable, is the lead segment empowering this growth.
It's an understatement to say there's been a lot of focus on our retransmission agreements in the last few weeks. These deals are critical to driving the Fox Networks' financial success to reflect its real value. Today, we have agreements in place with four of the largest distributors and have now set the market for our Broadcast business. Over the next couple of years as we continue to close new agreements, we will be taking this business to a whole new level of profitability.
However, the growth of our Network business is equally driven by a great and growing set of cable channels. From the incredible strength of FOX News to FX's original series like Sons of Anarchy and The League, the National Geographic event programming like Great Migrations to emerging sports networks like Fox Soccer and FUEL, our U.S. channels business continues to grow. The success of these channels has enabled us to continue to add subscribers, to earn fees that reflect the increased importance of our networks to customers and to drive great advertising growth.
Our Networks business outside the U.S. is an even more dynamic growth story as we take advantage of our leadership position in the emerging and growing international pay-TV market. This growth story continues to be big and broad. For example, a geographic region like Asia, which had previously not been a significant contributor as others, has really stepped up in the last quarter plus.
On a local level, our TV stations continue to do a great job about taking market share and driving efficiencies. And all our local, national and international TV businesses are continuing to benefit from a very strong advertising market. Our stations are looking at 20% year-on-year growth in the December quarter, while network scatter continues to be priced at double-digit increases to the upfront. While the broader economy still faces great uncertainty, there are no signs today that these anxieties are impacting the ad market as we begin to look beyond January 1. Nonetheless, we remain cautious and alert for the risks.
Our Networks business is our biggest. We have key initiatives underway across the company. In Italy, we've begun to recapture some of the growth that we had before the challenges with Berlusconi during the past 12 months plus. Our short-term priority has been top line growth, particularly subscribers. And we've begun to achieve those objectives through new pricing and packaging, technology leadership and re-energized marketing. We're certainly not declaring victory, but I believe we're making the right moves and making headway.
Germany is even more of a work in progress. However, there, again, I believe our management team is making the right moves and beginning to get things going in the right direction. We clearly have challenges ahead, but the market opportunity is unique and we have a real combination of content and technology leadership to build on.
In our Content businesses, Fox Film has had a disappointing few quarters without breakout hits. But it is important to note we equally have avoided any big loss films in an industry noted for them. We continue to be led by a management team that is second to none and one that knows how to manage this complicated business. We feel great about our big holiday releases and into next year. In addition, we're strengthening our business for the long term by reaching agreements with Jim Cameron, the next two Avatar films and concluding an extension to our film financing structure.
Our TV production business continues to prove its strength with series like Modern Family, which is well in its way to the highest first cycle per episode syndication cable revenues ever. From a Fox Network perspective, the new season has been a bit of a disappointment, and we would like to have a Game 6 in the World Series. But the strength of the NFL and the ad market has enabled us to largely offset those shortfalls. More importantly, we're very excited about the new energy at American Idol and the continued progress on X Factor for next fall, with the potential to build real year-round tent poles.
In our Publishing business, we continue to build on our leadership position in traditional print, with papers like The Wall Street Journal continuing to grow while others decline. At the same time, we're building a digital business for our news content that has a healthy and exciting future. These digital businesses will take time to emerge and the explosion of tablets the next few years will be a real driving force. We feel very good about the launch of our digital subscription product in the U.K. and believe that it provides a great foundation to build on.
The final business I want to touch on is MySpace. We've been clear that MySpace is a problem. We recognize that we had to redefine and largely rebuild this business. We believe the foundation was there to warrant this effort, and it has been our focus this year. We've made adjustments in the cost structure most recently by consolidating ad sales. And most importantly, in the last few weeks, we have relaunched MySpace with a focus on social entertainment. 
We feel really good about this relaunch product, and it has been generally well received by the opinion makers in the business, but we recognized the critical issue is building interest with consumers. We also recognize the challenges we face in doing so. The current losses are not acceptable or sustainable. Our current management did not create these losses, but they know we have to address them. I give them great credit for pouring their hearts and sweat into creating a great new MySpace experience that has the potential to be an exciting business for us. We equally know we need to make real headway in the coming quarters to get this business to a sustainable level.
Overall, when you have as many businesses in as many regions as we do, it is unlikely that they will all be operating in an optimum level on a short-term basis, although we strive to make sure most are. I believe our core job is to make sure we have great management teams running these businesses that we take advantage of opportunities, aggressively address problems and have plans in place to build long-term value in our increasingly complicated digital world. We believe we're achieving these goals. 
Thanks, and I'll turn it back to Dave and Reed and we're happy to take questions.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Operator, if we could take questions from the financial community, please.
componenttext: Operator, if we could take questions from the financial community, please.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have one for Chase on MySpace. You mentioned the relaunch. I wonder how much time needs to pass before you judge whether or not it's successful? And how do you judge whether or not it's successful? What are you looking for? And if it doesn't work, what
componenttext: I have one for Chase on MySpace. You mentioned the relaunch. I wonder how much time needs to pass before you judge whether or not it's successful? And how do you judge whether or not it's successful? What are you looking for? And if it doesn't work, what happens next? That's what I'm looking at.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not going to put a specific date. These are fluid businesses. But I think this is something we looked up judging quarters not in years. And I think our goal is to get to a place, essentially probably that has got a revenue, the top line that is g
componenttext: Yes, I'm not going to put a specific date. These are fluid businesses. But I think this is something we looked up judging quarters not in years. And I think our goal is to get to a place, essentially probably that has got a revenue, the top line that is going in the right direction and a clear path to profitability. And I think those are the goals we've set for that business. And I think the product we've launched, we feel really good about. We recognize we have to build an audience. We've got our audience. We've got still great reach that gives us the foundation to bring that audience to that product. But our traffic number is still not going in the right direction, and we have to stabilized that and have a predictable path forward and make sure we got the right cost structure. And again, a clear path to be a profitable business.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente, Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente, Barclays Capital.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one question for Chase. Had a question around your philosophy around making Fox TV studio content available on digital platforms. It seems as though to me you've been a bit more liberal in terms of the Fox content that's available on Hulu, fox.com. Y
componenttext: Just one question for Chase. Had a question around your philosophy around making Fox TV studio content available on digital platforms. It seems as though to me you've been a bit more liberal in terms of the Fox content that's available on Hulu, fox.com. You mentioned Modern Family in your opening comments, and I guess you've licensed the digital rights to ABC because you can watch the most recent episode of Modern Family on ABC.com. So I'm just wondering how that strategy is going, if you can give us an update on your thoughts there, and if you plan to continue along a more open path in terms of Fox content online.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, I'd just clarify that in shows like Modern Family, there are probably more ABC decisions based on rights or license. I'll talk about our shows, but probably the decisions you're citing on things like Modern Family are more driven by ABC as
componenttext: I guess, first, I'd just clarify that in shows like Modern Family, there are probably more ABC decisions based on rights or license. I'll talk about our shows, but probably the decisions you're citing on things like Modern Family are more driven by ABC as the network, the licenses, the network rights. I mean, I guess what I'd say is, as a broad-based statement, is I think this digital arena is clearly still evolving. I think it is important that we -- we're very focused on essentially how do you manage these rights and really, there are sort of a handful of key issues, what are the windows, what's the ad load and what's the pricing to the degree you're dealing with some form of payment structure. Obviously, it's what the product that goes in there. I think all those things are things we're evaluating. Obviously, in places like Hulu, we've talked about a subscription service to go with the pay service. I think as we go forward with our traditional distribution partners, it's important we deal with these issues constructively. We think the digital arena is a very important one, I think particularly the mobile platforms. I do think the iPad brings a whole new dimension of opportunities to the digital arena. But look, scarcity of our product is a tremendous value, and I think we need to make sure we manage that product, we manage its availability intelligently. And I think that is very much a work in progress, and I certainly wouldn't say today if we've got a set of rules in place that we're looking to as long-term rules. I think we learn as we go, and I think those practices will continue to evolve. And I do think it's important that the digital platforms continue to develop dual revenue stream options. I mean, I do think in a fragmenting world, it's difficult to rely solely on the advertising-supported platforms. And I do think dual revenue streams are critical. And those options to the digital world clearly are in even earlier stage than others. So I think this arena will evolve. I think you'll see how we manage content in that context, continue to evolve as these various business models evolve.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that comes from David Bank, RBC Markets.
componenttext: And that comes from David Bank, RBC Markets.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Kind of a follow up on the first question on the MySpace side. But there are a lot of kind of other operations in there within Other, and I was wondering if you could give some more color in terms of whether or not you saw room for operating improvement and what the order of magnitude could be for things like mobile or the Fox and network, or kind of maybe a refresher on what's in there, what's working, what can be working better and what the order of magnitude of improvement could be in the intermediate term.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: The businesses that are within Other are -- there's only two of the businesses, Fox Mobile and our news outdoor business and IGN related to MySpace. I would say that there's not substantial room for growth within those businesses.

componenttext: So it's pretty much just MySpace and that's the opportunity for improvement?

Your next question comes from the line of Tuna Amobi, Standard 
& Poor's.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So my question is on Avatar. So you decided to go with two more installments on that, and it seems like you say just put together the financing on that. Just trying to get a sense how you kind of frame the upside from this franchise? And it seems like you
componenttext: So my question is on Avatar. So you decided to go with two more installments on that, and it seems like you say just put together the financing on that. Just trying to get a sense how you kind of frame the upside from this franchise? And it seems like you are having a three-disc set out this November. And I believe you had a modestly successful rerelease of the title. So as you think about this franchise going forward, can you help us perhaps understand how the potential upside as you see it? I know you spent a significant amount on the marketing for the first installment, which obviously paid off. So I'm just trying to -- if you were to look out next two, three years, how can we kind of think about this franchise and the potential strategy which you intend to use to monetize that?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, if you -- I think the sequel is a whole different level, I mean, sequels to the most successful film ever by practically a factor of two. If you're talking I got two sequels, you can look at that. So there are a couple years -- they're a few
componenttext: Well, I mean, if you -- I think the sequel is a whole different level, I mean, sequels to the most successful film ever by practically a factor of two. If you're talking I got two sequels, you can look at that. So there are a couple years -- they're a few years down the road. But those are, obviously, enormous events, and I think that is a film without comparison or rival. An incredibly successful film, and obviously, an incredibly important franchise for us. I mean, it's really more than films. In many ways, this is a franchise for us to develop, and I think one of the great opportunities you get with these sequels is what the lead time and knowing the product you've got. It enables you to develop a lot more things around it, whether it's merchandise, licensing, games, a whole experience that sort of leads into this now that you'll have the anticipation coming towards it. So you really do need to think about it as a franchise that it's hard, those two sequel movies coming. In the short term, I mean, they're certainly important. We're excited about the home video product we got at Christmas. We still haven't exploited really the 3D home entertainment experience because the 3D market is still in its infancy, so that opportunity is down the road. I mean, this is a franchise without comparison that we need to continue to make sure we in every way possible, and I do think the digital world opens up an array of these front [indiscernible] develop.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Just a quick follow up, Chase. Without going into more details on the deal with James Cameron, would you say the terms are roughly better or worse or the same for the coming installment?

componenttext: We don't get into terms, I mean, on terms that we have with key talents. We're very happy with it. We're thrilled to have the pictures. We're thrilled to be working with Jim. He is a unique talent, and these are great franchises for us.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: It comes from Richard Greenfield, BTIG.
componenttext: It comes from Richard Greenfield, BTIG.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions, one on retransmission consent. Cablevision put out a press release when the signal got restored the other day, basically saying that they have actually gotten better terms by basically removing programming for a couple of weeks or losing ac
componenttext: Two questions, one on retransmission consent. Cablevision put out a press release when the signal got restored the other day, basically saying that they have actually gotten better terms by basically removing programming for a couple of weeks or losing access to programming for a couple of weeks. And was just curious, how do you react to that? And two, if that were actually true, does that mean we're going to see a lot more of these protracted battles with loss programming because there actually is a benefit to the distributor by going to that level? And then two, can you just update us on the BSkyB transaction, saw that you filed today. And just was wondering what you're expecting now versus kind of the original time frame that you laid out back when the original deal was announced and kind of what you're thinking in terms of best case, worst case for an approval process?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, actually, I didn't see it. The stuff I saw from Cablevision was more sort of essentially complaining that the government didn't get involved. I mean, I guess I'm not sure. I mean, look, we were pretty clear with what we were trying to get. And I'm
componenttext: I mean, actually, I didn't see it. The stuff I saw from Cablevision was more sort of essentially complaining that the government didn't get involved. I mean, I guess I'm not sure. I mean, look, we were pretty clear with what we were trying to get. And I'm not going to sort of go through what were private negotiations in public. But we feel good about where we are. And they were pretty clear about what they were trying to do, was drag the government into it. We don't think the government needed to be into it. In reality, I think it would have been helpful if the government said up front they weren't. They made up few noises that probably made the process more difficult not -- or made it more extracted. I mean, I think protracted. I think if the government had been clear up front that they were going to stay out of it, it was a private matter between private parties, it may not have gone off the air at all. But I think that what they were trying to do was pretty clear all along, is drag government in. And I think it became clear that the government, while there are array of parties putting out releases, that this is a battle to be dealt with between private parties. And we reached an agreement that we feel very good about. And BSkyB, I mean, what we filed today, I mean, other than what I think is out public, I'm not sure there's a whole lot, I think that the EU have said they'll answer by some date in early December.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: December the 8th.
componenttext: December the 8th.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think the U.K. has said they'll position earlier or something. And I don't think there's a whole lot more color than that.
componenttext: And I think the U.K. has said they'll position earlier or something. And I don't think there's a whole lot more color than that.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chase, last year your Cable Network margins increased about 500 basis points over the prior year. This first quarter, they're up another 400 to 500 basis points. Is this first quarter margin of 35.2% something that could be representative for the year? I
componenttext: Chase, last year your Cable Network margins increased about 500 basis points over the prior year. This first quarter, they're up another 400 to 500 basis points. Is this first quarter margin of 35.2% something that could be representative for the year? I realize your margins are lower than a lot of your competitors, but how long can you keep growing the margins at this kind of a rate?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we clearly believe we have room in an array of fronts to continue to drive this number of our channels, I mean, I guess in many ways. I mean, there are channels that aren't fully distributed that we are continuing to add distribution. Obviously, whe
componenttext: Well, we clearly believe we have room in an array of fronts to continue to drive this number of our channels, I mean, I guess in many ways. I mean, there are channels that aren't fully distributed that we are continuing to add distribution. Obviously, when we add subscribers to the channel, it's pretty much is pure bottom line. A number of the recent deals, even including on big channels, expanded that distribution, the quality of the channels. And I guess something like FOX News as it continues to drive forward in the next year plus. We will move into a new round of renewals on FOX News. So again, it sort of the up-front comments. It's really three things that kind of really all improved those margins sort of, again, additional -- I'm not talking domestic now, additional subscribers getting affiliate rates that reflect the value of the channels and the audience that comes with it in terms of advertising. Probably even more so domestic -- I mean, internationally, because in internationally you've got channels that expand that reach at an even things like subscriber growth or an even faster rate when you look at places like Latin America and the rate of growth there. So I think we clearly have real room to grow. And as we've said competitively, when you look at our channels against those we compete with, they are much less mature channels. They have not been around as long and therefore, the positive ends of things, they've got I think, disproportionately more growth ahead of them. And I think those channels continue to really operate well. And again, whether it's News or FX and its originals, channels did really perform well. And we feel very good about the ability to continue to drive those businesses forward.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow on, the industry showed in the second quarter down domestic, down multichannel homes. Are you seeing that in any of your -- had a feature generating from any of your fully generated, fully distributed channels? Are you seeing fewer subs than t
componenttext: As a follow on, the industry showed in the second quarter down domestic, down multichannel homes. Are you seeing that in any of your -- had a feature generating from any of your fully generated, fully distributed channels? Are you seeing fewer subs than the prior quarter?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, and in fact, I think we'd been looking at, actually, subs going up. But I think an awful lot was read into that. I mean, if you get this court-cutting issue, I just don't see it. I mean, realistically, I mean, I think getting us to second or third qua
componenttext: No, and in fact, I think we'd been looking at, actually, subs going up. But I think an awful lot was read into that. I mean, if you get this court-cutting issue, I just don't see it. I mean, realistically, I mean, I think getting us to second or third quarter, a mature market, we're probably -- we'll look out for quarters that Cable down a bit, and satellite and telco is still up. And I guess really just the fundamental service that for American households is a fundamental part of what they do with their time and what they value in their life and one that I think is a service without comparison. But for now, we would not be seeing them.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that comes from the line of James Mitchell, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And that comes from the line of James Mitchell, Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: Yes, really, we're not going to get into specifics in terms of terms with any one party or really terms in general. I guess what I'd say is the RSNs continue to be a really good business for us, I think, they as well as our other cable channels. We're achieving our objectives and continuing to drive those businesses forward.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: The next question is from Adam Alexander, Goldman Sachs.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question for Chase on the international channel. It looks to be a very strong result in that division. Can you just break out a little bit more specifically where that growth is coming from? Is it ad market, affiliate fee or new channel launches? A
componenttext: Just a question for Chase on the international channel. It looks to be a very strong result in that division. Can you just break out a little bit more specifically where that growth is coming from? Is it ad market, affiliate fee or new channel launches? And how much is the weak U.S. dollar benefiting in that division?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The dollar helps some, but that's not the driving force. I mean, I used the phrase big and broad, I think, in the opening comments and that's what it is. I mean, it is multiregional, multichannel. There's Latin America, Europe, I cited Asia. I mean, on As
componenttext: The dollar helps some, but that's not the driving force. I mean, I used the phrase big and broad, I think, in the opening comments and that's what it is. I mean, it is multiregional, multichannel. There's Latin America, Europe, I cited Asia. I mean, on Asia, I'm actually excluding India. So it's not talking about STAR, which equally has been good. It's a good story. The ad dollars are equally. I mean, the ad dollars, I think, were in the mid-20s year-on-year increases. But those channels may continue to -- [indiscernible] they are really good and strengthening channels. I think you got to have the quality to deliver. But it is a broad regional story and a multichannel story that has both affiliate and the dollar strength behind it.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think that business is ahead of what you probably would have expected 12 months ago?
componenttext: Do you think that business is ahead of what you probably would have expected 12 months ago?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, look, they've probably to their credit. I guess I've been here for four quarters, and I think that, gee, in every quarter they've beaten the target I gave them. So they've done a really a good job as have the STAR guys, really. I mean, the ST
componenttext: Yes. I mean, look, they've probably to their credit. I guess I've been here for four quarters, and I think that, gee, in every quarter they've beaten the target I gave them. So they've done a really a good job as have the STAR guys, really. I mean, the STAR guys have -- same thing. I mean, I think it's not just riding the wave, and I do think it's not just saying it's a market. I mean, I think they're doing a really good job executing and creating quality channels that stand out and have a real value. When you look at the market share of our channels combined in some of these places in Latin America, Europe, it's extraordinary. And I think we have a real position of leadership that we can really build on.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Bazinet, Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Bazinet, Citi.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: I just had two housekeeping questions. If I'm doing the math right, is the sale of Easynet at BSkyB, did that impact your earnings about $0.02? And did the favorable FX help your operating income growth about 2 percentage points in the quarter? If you could just confirm.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Jason, it's $0.01 a share on Easynet, and the currency in the quarter is really -- it's marginal.
componenttext: No. Jason, it's $0.01 a share on Easynet, and the currency in the quarter is really -- it's marginal.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that comes from Ben Swinburne, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And that comes from Ben Swinburne, Morgan Stanley.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chase, I wanted to go back to the network. You talked about retransmission revenue, which clearly News Corp. has led the charge on and gotten the math for. But I was wondering on the cost side, as you look at the network and particularly sports, how you'r
componenttext: Chase, I wanted to go back to the network. You talked about retransmission revenue, which clearly News Corp. has led the charge on and gotten the math for. But I was wondering on the cost side, as you look at the network and particularly sports, how you're thinking about this business over the long term. I think Fox, I believe probably spends more on sports programming than any other network. You've got, in addition to the NFL, baseball, NASCAR, is there something you think needs to change over the long term? Do you think the retrans revenue stream fixes the business given how much sports costs? Or you want to see that move more and more to your cable properties where you've built, obviously, a Regional Sports Network business that's very attractive?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I mean and I guess on the last point, I mean, I really think that about our Broadcast Network more and more should be thought of in the same way as Cable Network. And therefore, I don't -- and I know that you're differentiating one from the o
componenttext: Well, first, I mean and I guess on the last point, I mean, I really think that about our Broadcast Network more and more should be thought of in the same way as Cable Network. And therefore, I don't -- and I know that you're differentiating one from the other. They've got to become dual revenue businesses that receive revenues that are reflective of their strength, and that's what we're driving the Fox Network to be. It's a business that looks essentially much more like our Cable Networks. I guess in the sport line, sports programming is always a double-edged sword. It has great strength, great value. Look at the NFL right now. In a world of fragmentation, it continues to set records. As I said, we like another World Series game or two and that's the variation in it, but it's still great content in baseball. The programming has great appeal. Sports has a unique strength in the world of DVRs and all the like. There isn't anything like it. There isn't a second World Series or a second Super Bowl or a second NFC Championship Game. And it has a unique value in the marketplace. The issue with it is they come with big price tags. And it's been a great part of building Fox. We'd like it to continue to be a part of building Fox. But we've got to negotiate rates that enable us to believe it makes sense. I think our goal -- we think it has been important, it's been valuable to us. We'd like it to continue to be a part of our story, but we've got to make sure it's on terms that makes sense. Obviously, retransmission does help. I mean, I think it's -- if you've been an ad-supported only, an asset only business, I think probably over time you wouldn't find any of these sports on any of the networks on that business model. But I think as they build the business model, that enables them to compete in a more level playing field. It has profitable businesses with exciting long-term futures, and it enable to compete for rights. But as with any rights, you've got to be disciplined. And at some point, rights get too expensive, the rights we clearly like to have and I'd certainly put sports rights in that category.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow up to some of the earlier calls on digital distribution, TV Everywhere and authentication is starting to come to fruition a little bit in the market. But you've made some waves around Google TV. I think someone from Google was quoted
componenttext: And just as a follow up to some of the earlier calls on digital distribution, TV Everywhere and authentication is starting to come to fruition a little bit in the market. But you've made some waves around Google TV. I think someone from Google was quoted in the press as saying the broadcasters don't get it. And one question I'm wondering if you would address is are you thinking about different devices or different screens as a way to window this content, which is a little bit of a nuance versus how we typically think about windowing, which is just the calendar? In other words, would you make content available on a mobile platform or on a PC, but disable it on the television screen? How do you think about that piece of the story?

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think in the house, the difference between screens, I mean, is going to continue to diminish their sort of PC and TV as you get more Internet-ready TVs and the like. I do think mobile is probably a more discrete platform that is obviously different beca
componenttext: I think in the house, the difference between screens, I mean, is going to continue to diminish their sort of PC and TV as you get more Internet-ready TVs and the like. I do think mobile is probably a more discrete platform that is obviously different because it has the really get it anywhere. I do think the iPad or the tablet devices are really going to redefine that whole mobile experience. So it's very early stages, and I think what will be the true -- I think the apps will grow fast now to the next couple of years. You'll really start to have a big enough universe out there to meaningfully determine how do you develop -- how do we build on that opportunity. It is a real opportunity for us. Then I'm not sure if you went into the home system with the screens, the way longer term -- I think in the short term, it can exist. But I do think those screens are going to blend. And I think it does come back to figuring out probably more what is the business models for our content and what are the right terms, and I think we need to -- you're right, our content is tremendously valuable. We need to manage it. We need to make sure as we make it available, we're making it available on the right terms and much as like the movie business has done historically, creating a series of windows that went from theatrical to video to pay to free. Now it's talking about a VOD window that may be ahead of the DVD window that you continue to figure how do you create the right windows on the right business terms. I do think one of the things that I would get public about and people talk about, broadcasters versus cable, and I think that distinction is sort of ill-founded. I mean, in essence, if you're going to create original programming on a cable channel, why is that sort of one set of rules versus great original programming on a network. I mean, it's great original programming. You ought to manage it accordingly, figure out how do you exploit that programming. I think it's a good thing for us to enable our customers to access that programming in new and exciting and interesting ways. I think that it's a great opportunity for us to do that. But we need to do it in ways that have us fairly compensated for the value of our content. Our content is incredibly valuable. You can't just throw it out there to everybody. We got to make sure that we're putting it out there on terms that get us fairly compensated for the content we create.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Comes from Tom Eagan, Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Comes from Tom Eagan, Collins Stewart.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Just on Home Entertainment revenue, Chase. I think at Time Warner they said that year-to-date, their home entertainment revenue was up about 8%. What was your date so far at News Corp.?

componenttext: I think it's actually up about 10%. And the Home Entertainment business, because sort of a lot of people are sort of going down, it's actually stabilized for us and actually even some segments that were going down, we're actually seeing some nice light in right now.

headline: News Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
